args.name: domain
args.description: (Required) The domain of the certificate to look up. If no certificate is found with this name, an error will be returned.

args.name: statuses
args.description:
(Optional) A list of statuses on which to filter the returned list. Valid values are PENDING_VALIDATION, ISSUED,
INACTIVE, EXPIRED, VALIDATION_TIMED_OUT, REVOKED and FAILED. If no value is specified, only certificates in the ISSUED state
are returned.

args.name: types
args.description: (Optional) A list of types on which to filter the returned list. Valid values are AMAZON_ISSUED and IMPORTED.

args.name: most_recent
args.description: (Optional) If set to true, it sorts the certificates matched by previous criteria by the NotBefore field, returning only the most recent one. If set to false, it returns an error if more than one certificate is found. Defaults to false.

attrs.name: arn
attrs.description: Set to the ARN of the found certificate, suitable for referencing in other resources that support ACM certificates.

(Optional) If more than one result is returned, use the most
recent AMI.

args.name: executable_users
args.description:
(Optional) Limit search to users with explicit launch permission on
the image. Valid items are the numeric account ID or self.

args.name: filter
args.description:
(Optional) One or more name/value pairs to filter off of. There are
several valid keys, for a full reference, check out
describe-images in the AWS CLI reference.

args.name: owners
args.description:
(Optional) Limit search to specific AMI owners. Valid items are the numeric
account ID, amazon, or self.

args.name: name_regex
args.description:
(Optional) A regex string to apply to the AMI list returned
by AWS. This allows more advanced filtering not supported from the AWS API. This
filtering is done locally on what AWS returns, and could have a performance
impact if the result is large. It is recommended to combine this with other
options to narrow down the list AWS returns.

attrs.name: architecture
attrs.description: The OS architecture of the AMI (ie: i386 or x86_64).

attrs.name: block_device_mappings
attrs.description:
The block device mappings of the AMI.
block_device_mappings.#.device_name - The physical name of the device.
block_device_mappings.#.ebs.delete_on_termination - true if the EBS volume
will be deleted on termination.
block_device_mappings.#.ebs.encrypted - true if the EBS volume
is encrypted.
block_device_mappings.#.ebs.iops - 0 if the EBS volume is
not a provisioned IOPS image, otherwise the supported IOPS count.
block_device_mappings.#.ebs.snapshot_id - The ID of the snapshot.
block_device_mappings.#.ebs.volume_size - The size of the volume, in GiB.
block_device_mappings.#.ebs.volume_type - The volume type.
block_device_mappings.#.no_device - Suppresses the specified device
included in the block device mapping of the AMI.
block_device_mappings.#.virtual_name - The virtual device name (for
instance stores).

args.name: snapshot_type
args.description:
(Optional) The type of snapshots to be returned. If you don't specify a SnapshotType 
value, then both automated and manual snapshots are returned. Shared and public DB snapshots are not 
included in the returned results by default. Possible values are, automated, manual, shared and public.

args.name: include_shared
args.description:
(Optional) Set this value to true to include shared manual DB snapshots from other 
AWS accounts that this AWS account has been given permission to copy or restore, otherwise set this value to false. 
The default is false.

args.name: include_public
args.description:
(Optional) Set this value to true to include manual DB snapshots that are public and can be 
copied or restored by any AWS account, otherwise set this value to false. The default is false.

args.name: policy_id
args.description: (Optional)  An ID for the policy document.

args.name: source_json
args.description:
(Optional)  An IAM policy document to import as a base for the
current policy document.  Statements with non-blank sids in the current
policy document will overwrite statements with the same sid in the source
json.  Statements without an sid cannot be overwritten.

args.name: override_json
args.description:
(Optional)  An IAM policy document to import and override the
current policy document.  Statements with non-blank sids in the override
document will overwrite statements with the same sid in the current document.
Statements without an sid cannot be overwritten.

args.name: statement
args.description:
(Required)  A nested configuration block (described below)
configuring one statement to be included in the policy document.

args.name: sid
args.description: (Optional)  An ID for the policy statement.

args.name: effect
args.description:
(Optional)  Either "Allow" or "Deny", to specify whether this
statement allows or denies the given actions. The default is "Allow".

args.name: actions
args.description:
(Optional)  A list of actions that this statement either allows
or denies. For example, ["ec2:RunInstances", "s3:*"].

args.name: not_actions
args.description:
(Optional)  A list of actions that this statement does not
apply to. Used to apply a policy statement to all actions except those
listed.

args.name: resources
args.description:
(Optional)  A list of resource ARNs that this statement applies
to. This is required by AWS if used for an IAM policy.

args.name: not_resources
args.description:
(Optional)  A list of resource ARNs that this statement
does not apply to. Used to apply a policy statement to all resources
except those listed.

args.name: principals
args.description:
(Optional)  A nested configuration block (described below)
specifying a resource (or resource pattern) to which this statement applies.

args.name: not_principals
args.description:
(Optional)  Like principals except gives resources that
the statement does not apply to.

args.name: condition
args.description:
(Optional)  A nested configuration block (described below)
that defines a further, possibly-service-specific condition that constrains
whether this statement applies.

args.name: test
args.description:
(Required) The name of the
IAM condition type
to evaluate.

args.name: variable
args.description:
(Required) The name of a
Context Variable
to apply the condition to. Context variables may either be standard AWS
variables starting with aws:, or servicespecific variables prefixed with
the service name.

args.name: values
args.description:
(Required) The values to evaluate the condition against. If multiple
values are provided, the condition matches if at least one of them applies.
(That is, the tests are combined with the "OR" boolean operation.)

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The type of principal. For AWS accounts this is "AWS".

args.name: identifiers
args.description:
(Required) List of identifiers for principals. When type
is "AWS", these are IAM user or role ARNs.

attrs.name: json
attrs.description: The above arguments serialized as a standard JSON policy document.

args.name: integration_http_method
args.description:
(Optional) The integration HTTP method
(GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, HEAD, OPTION) specifying how API Gateway will interact with the back end.
Required if type is AWS, AWS_PROXY, HTTP or HTTP_PROXY.
Not all methods are compatible with all AWS integrations.
e.g. Lambda function can only be invoked via POST.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The integration input's type. Valid values are HTTP (for HTTP backends), MOCK (not calling any real backend), AWS (for AWS services), AWS_PROXY (for Lambda proxy integration) and HTTP_PROXY (for HTTP proxy integration).

args.name: uri
args.description:
(Optional) The input's URI (HTTP, AWS). Required if type is HTTP or AWS.
For HTTP integrations, the URI must be a fully formed, encoded HTTP(S) URL according to the RFC-3986 specification . For AWS integrations, the URI should be of the form arn:aws:apigateway:{region}:{subdomain.service|service}:{path|action}/{service_api}. region, subdomain and service are used to determine the right endpoint.
e.g. arn:aws:apigateway:eu-west-1:lambda:path/2015-03-31/functions/arn:aws:lambda:eu-west-1:012345678901:function:my-func/invocations

args.name: credentials
args.description: (Optional) The credentials required for the integration. For AWS integrations, 2 options are available. To specify an IAM Role for Amazon API Gateway to assume, use the role's ARN. To require that the caller's identity be passed through from the request, specify the string arn:aws:iam::\*:user/\*.

args.description:

For example: request_parameters = { "integration.request.header.X-Some-Other-Header" = "method.request.header.X-Some-Header" }

args.name: passthrough_behavior
args.description: (Optional) The integration passthrough behavior (WHEN_NO_MATCH, WHEN_NO_TEMPLATES, NEVER).  Required if request_templates is used.

args.description: (Optional) Specifies how to handle request payload content type conversions. Supported values are CONVERT_TO_BINARY and CONVERT_TO_TEXT. If this property is not defined, the request payload will be passed through from the method request to integration request without modification, provided that the passthroughBehaviors is configured to support payload pass-through.

an integration response based on the response from the backend. Setting this to - makes the integration the default one.
If the backend is an AWS Lambda function, the AWS Lambda function error header is matched.
For all other HTTP and AWS backends, the HTTP status code is matched.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the policy.

args.name: policy_type
args.description: (Optional) For DynamoDB, only TargetTrackingScaling is supported. For any other service, only StepScaling is supported. Defaults to StepScaling.

args.name: resource_id
args.description: (Required) The resource type and unique identifier string for the resource associated with the scaling policy. Documentation can be found in the ResourceId parameter at: AWS Application Auto Scaling API Reference

args.name: scalable_dimension
args.description: (Required) The scalable dimension of the scalable target. Documentation can be found in the ScalableDimension parameter at: AWS Application Auto Scaling API Reference

args.name: service_namespace
args.description: (Required) The AWS service namespace of the scalable target. Documentation can be found in the ServiceNamespace parameter at: AWS Application Auto Scaling API Reference

args.name: step_scaling_policy_configuration
args.description: (Optional) Step scaling policy configuration, requires policy_type = "StepScaling" (default). See supported fields below.

args.name: adjustment_type
args.description: (Required) Specifies whether the adjustment is an absolute number or a percentage of the current capacity. Valid values are ChangeInCapacity, ExactCapacity, and PercentChangeInCapacity.

args.name: cooldown
args.description: (Required) The amount of time, in seconds, after a scaling activity completes and before the next scaling activity can start.

args.name: metric_aggregation_type
args.description: (Optional) The aggregation type for the policy's metrics. Valid values are "Minimum", "Maximum", and "Average". Without a value, AWS will treat the aggregation type as "Average".

args.name: min_adjustment_magnitude
args.description: (Optional) The minimum number to adjust your scalable dimension as a result of a scaling activity. If the adjustment type is PercentChangeInCapacity, the scaling policy changes the scalable dimension of the scalable target by this amount.

args.name: metric_interval_lower_bound
args.description: (Optional) The lower bound for the difference between the alarm threshold and the CloudWatch metric. Without a value, AWS will treat this bound as infinity.

args.name: metric_interval_upper_bound
args.description: (Optional) The upper bound for the difference between the alarm threshold and the CloudWatch metric. Without a value, AWS will treat this bound as infinity. The upper bound must be greater than the lower bound.

args.name: scaling_adjustment
args.description: (Required) The number of members by which to scale, when the adjustment bounds are breached. A positive value scales up. A negative value scales down.

args.name: step_adjustment
args.description:
(Optional) A set of adjustments that manage scaling. These have the following structure:
step_adjustment {
  metric_interval_lower_bound = 1.0
  metric_interval_upper_bound = 2.0
  scaling_adjustment = -1
}
step_adjustment {
  metric_interval_lower_bound = 2.0
  metric_interval_upper_bound = 3.0
  scaling_adjustment = 1
}


metric_interval_lower_bound - (Optional) The lower bound for the difference between the alarm threshold and the CloudWatch metric. Without a value, AWS will treat this bound as infinity.
metric_interval_upper_bound - (Optional) The upper bound for the difference between the alarm threshold and the CloudWatch metric. Without a value, AWS will treat this bound as infinity. The upper bound must be greater than the lower bound.
scaling_adjustment - (Required) The number of members by which to scale, when the adjustment bounds are breached. A positive value scales up. A negative value scales down.

args.name: target_tracking_scaling_policy_configuration
args.description: (Optional) A target tracking policy, requires policy_type = "TargetTrackingScaling". See supported fields below.

args.name: target_value
args.description: (Optional) The target value for the metric.

args.name: disable_scale_in
args.description: (Optional) Indicates whether scale in by the target tracking policy is disabled. If the value is true, scale in is disabled and the target tracking policy won't remove capacity from the scalable resource. Otherwise, scale in is enabled and the target tracking policy can remove capacity from the scalable resource. The default value is false.

args.name: scale_in_cooldown
args.description: (Optional) The amount of time, in seconds, after a scale in activity completes before another scale in activity can start.

args.name: scale_out_cooldown
args.description: (Optional) The amount of time, in seconds, after a scale out activity completes before another scale out activity can start.

Documentation can be found in the parameter at: AWS Application Auto Scaling API Reference

args.description: (Required) The name for your compute environment. Up to 128 letters (uppercase and lowercase), numbers, and underscores are allowed.

args.name: compute_resources
args.description: (Optional) Details of the compute resources managed by the compute environment. This parameter is required for managed compute environments. See details below.

args.name: bid_percentage
args.description: (Optional) The minimum percentage that a Spot Instance price must be when compared with the On-Demand price for that instance type before instances are launched. For example, if your bid percentage is 20%, then the Spot price must be below 20% of the current On-Demand price for that EC2 instance. This parameter is required for SPOT compute environments.

args.name: desired_vcpus
args.description: (Optional) The desired number of EC2 vCPUS in the compute environment.

args.description: (Optional) The EC2 key pair that is used for instances launched in the compute environment.

args.name: instance_type
args.description: (Required) A list of instance types that may be launched.

args.name: max_vcpus
args.description: (Required) The maximum number of EC2 vCPUs that an environment can reach.

args.name: min_vcpus
args.description: (Required) The minimum number of EC2 vCPUs that an environment should maintain.

args.name: security_group_ids
args.description: (Required) A list of EC2 security group that are associated with instances launched in the compute environment.

args.name: spot_iam_fleet_role
args.description: (Optional) The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon EC2 Spot Fleet IAM role applied to a SPOT compute environment. This parameter is required for SPOT compute environments.

args.name: subnets
args.description: (Required) A list of VPC subnets into which the compute resources are launched.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) Key-value pair tags to be applied to resources that are launched in the compute environment.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The type of compute environment. Valid items are EC2 or SPOT.

args.name: service_role
args.description: (Required) The full Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that allows AWS Batch to make calls to other AWS services on your behalf.

args.name: state
args.description: (Optional) The state of the compute environment. If the state is ENABLED, then the compute environment accepts jobs from a queue and can scale out automatically based on queues. Valid items are ENABLED or DISABLED. Defaults to ENABLED.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The type of the compute environment. Valid items are MANAGED or UNMANAGED.

attrs.name: arn

attrs.name: ecs_cluster_arn
attrs.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the underlying Amazon ECS cluster used by the compute environment.

attrs.name: status
attrs.description: The current status of the compute environment (for example, CREATING or VALID).

attrs.name: status_reason
attrs.description: A short, human-readable string to provide additional details about the current status of the compute environment.

args.name: name

args.name: template_body
args.description: (Optional) Structure containing the template body (max size: 51,200 bytes).

args.name: template_url
args.description: (Optional) Location of a file containing the template body (max size: 460,800 bytes).

args.name: capabilities
args.description:
(Optional) A list of capabilities.
Valid values: CAPABILITY_IAM or CAPABILITY_NAMED_IAM

args.name: disable_rollback
args.description:
(Optional) Set to true to disable rollback of the stack if stack creation failed.
Conflicts with on_failure.

args.name: notification_arns
args.description: (Optional) A list of SNS topic ARNs to publish stack related events.

args.name: on_failure
args.description:
(Optional) Action to be taken if stack creation fails. This must be
one of: DO_NOTHING, ROLLBACK, or DELETE. Conflicts with disable_rollback.

args.name: parameters
args.description: (Optional) A list of Parameter structures that specify input parameters for the stack.

args.name: policy_body
args.description:
(Optional) Structure containing the stack policy body.
Conflicts w/ policy_url.

args.name: policy_url
args.description:
(Optional) Location of a file containing the stack policy.
Conflicts w/ policy_body.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A list of tags to associate with this stack.

args.name: iam_role_arn
args.description: (Optional) The ARN of an IAM role that AWS CloudFormation assumes to create the stack. If you don't specify a value, AWS CloudFormation uses the role that was previously associated with the stack. If no role is available, AWS CloudFormation uses a temporary session that is generated from your user credentials.

args.name: timeout_in_minutes
args.description: (Optional) The amount of time that can pass before the stack status becomes CREATE_FAILED.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: A unique identifier of the stack.

attrs.name: outputs
attrs.description: A map of outputs from the stack.

args.name: aliases
args.description:
(Optional)  Extra CNAMEs (alternate domain names), if any, for
this distribution.

args.name: cache_behavior
args.description:
(Optional)  A cache behavior
resource for this distribution (multiples allowed).

args.name: allowed_methods
args.description:
(Required)  Controls which HTTP methods CloudFront
processes and forwards to your Amazon S3 bucket or your custom origin.

args.name: cached_methods
args.description:
(Required)  Controls whether CloudFront caches the
response to requests using the specified HTTP methods.

args.name: compress
args.description:
(Optional)  Whether you want CloudFront to automatically
compress content for web requests that include Accept-Encoding: gzip in
the request header (default: false).

args.name: default_ttl
args.description:
(Required)  The default amount of time (in seconds) that an
object is in a CloudFront cache before CloudFront forwards another request
in the absence of an Cache-Control max-age or Expires header.

args.name: forwarded_values
args.description:
(Required)  The forwarded values configuration that specifies how CloudFront
handles query strings, cookies and headers (maximum one).

args.name: lambda_function_association
args.description:
(Optional)  A config block that triggers a lambda function with
specific actions. Defined below, maximum 4.

args.name: max_ttl
args.description:
(Required)  The maximum amount of time (in seconds) that an
object is in a CloudFront cache before CloudFront forwards another request
to your origin to determine whether the object has been updated. Only
effective in the presence of Cache-Control max-age, Cache-Control
s-maxage, and Expires headers.

args.name: min_ttl
args.description:
(Required)  The minimum amount of time that you want objects to
stay in CloudFront caches before CloudFront queries your origin to see
whether the object has been updated.

args.name: path_pattern
args.description:
(Required)  The pattern (for example, images/*.jpg) that
specifies which requests you want this cache behavior to apply to.

args.name: smooth_streaming
args.description:
(Optional)  Indicates whether you want to distribute
media files in Microsoft Smooth Streaming format using the origin that is
associated with this cache behavior.

args.name: target_origin_id
args.description:
(Required)  The value of ID for the origin that you want
CloudFront to route requests to when a request matches the path pattern
either for a cache behavior or for the default cache behavior.

args.name: trusted_signers
args.description:
(Optional)  The AWS accounts, if any, that you want to
allow to create signed URLs for private content.

args.name: viewer_protocol_policy
args.description:
(Required)  Use this element to specify the
protocol that users can use to access the files in the origin specified by
TargetOriginId when a request matches the path pattern in PathPattern. One
of allow-all, https-only, or redirect-to-https.

args.name: comment
args.description:
(Optional)  Any comments you want to include about the
distribution.

args.name: custom_error_response
args.description: (Optional)  One or more custom error response elements (multiples allowed).

args.name: error_caching_min_ttl
args.description:
(Optional)  The minimum amount of time you want
HTTP error codes to stay in CloudFront caches before CloudFront queries your
origin to see whether the object has been updated.

args.name: error_code
args.description:
(Required)  The 4xx or 5xx HTTP status code that you want to
customize.

args.name: response_code
args.description:
(Optional)  The HTTP status code that you want CloudFront
to return with the custom error page to the viewer.

args.name: response_page_path
args.description:
(Optional)  The path of the custom error page (for
example, /custom_404.html).

args.name: default_cache_behavior
args.description:
(Required)  The default cache behavior for this distribution (maximum
one).

args.name: default_root_object
args.description:
(Optional)  The object that you want CloudFront to
return (for example, index.html) when an end user requests the root URL.

args.name: enabled
args.description:
(Required)  Whether the distribution is enabled to accept end
user requests for content.

args.name: is_ipv6_enabled
args.description: (Optional)  Whether the IPv6 is enabled for the distribution.

args.name: http_version
args.description:
(Optional)  The maximum HTTP version to support on the
distribution. Allowed values are http1.1 and http2. The default is
http2.

args.name: logging_config
args.description:
(Optional)  The logging
configuration that controls how logs are written
to your distribution (maximum one).

args.name: bucket
args.description:
(Required)  The Amazon S3 bucket to store the access logs in, for
example, myawslogbucket.s3.amazonaws.com.

args.name: include_cookies
args.description:
(Optional)  Specifies whether you want CloudFront to
include cookies in access logs (default: false).

args.name: prefix
args.description:
(Optional)  An optional string that you want CloudFront to prefix
to the access log filenames for this distribution, for example, myprefix/.

args.name: origin
args.description:
(Required)  One or more origins for this
distribution (multiples allowed).

args.name: custom_origin_config
args.description:
The CloudFront custom
origin configuration information. If an S3
origin is required, use s3_origin_config instead.

args.name: domain_name
args.description:
(Required)  The DNS domain name of either the S3 bucket, or
web site of your custom origin.

args.name: custom_header
args.description:
(Optional)  One or more sub-resources with name and
value parameters that specify header data that will be sent to the origin
(multiples allowed).

args.name: origin_id
args.description: (Required)  A unique identifier for the origin.

args.name: origin_path
args.description:
(Optional)  An optional element that causes CloudFront to
request your content from a directory in your Amazon S3 bucket or your
custom origin.

args.name: s3_origin_config
args.description:
The CloudFront S3 origin
configuration information. If a custom origin is required, use
custom_origin_config instead.

args.name: http_port
args.description: (Required)  The HTTP port the custom origin listens on.

args.name: https_port
args.description: (Required)  The HTTPS port the custom origin listens on.

args.name: origin_protocol_policy
args.description:
(Required)  The origin protocol policy to apply to
your origin. One of http-only, https-only, or match-viewer.

args.name: origin_ssl_protocols
args.description:
(Required)  The SSL/TLS protocols that you want
CloudFront to use when communicating with your origin over HTTPS. A list of
one or more of SSLv3, TLSv1, TLSv1.1, and TLSv1.2.

args.name: origin_keepalive_timeout
args.description: (Optional) The Custom KeepAlive timeout, in seconds. By default, AWS enforces a limit of 60. But you can request an increase.

args.name: origin_read_timeout
args.description: (Optional) The Custom Read timeout, in seconds. By default, AWS enforces a limit of 60. But you can request an increase.

args.name: origin_access_identity
args.description:
(Optional)  The CloudFront origin access
identity to associate with the origin.

args.name: price_class
args.description:
(Optional)  The price class for this distribution. One of
PriceClass_All, PriceClass_200, PriceClass_100

args.name: restrictions
args.description:
(Required)  The restriction
configuration for this distribution (maximum one).

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.

args.name: viewer_certificate
args.description:
(Required)  The SSL
configuration for this distribution (maximum
one).

args.name: acm_certificate_arn
args.description:
The ARN of the AWS Certificate Manager
certificate that you wish to use with this distribution. Specify this,
cloudfront_default_certificate, or iam_certificate_id.  The ACM
certificate must be in  US-EAST-1.

args.name: cloudfront_default_certificate
args.description:
true if you want viewers to use HTTPS
to request your objects and you're using the CloudFront domain name for your
distribution. Specify this, acm_certificate_arn, or iam_certificate_id.

args.name: iam_certificate_id
args.description:
The IAM certificate identifier of the custom viewer
certificate for this distribution if you are using a custom domain. Specify
this, acm_certificate_arn, or cloudfront_default_certificate.

args.name: minimum_protocol_version
args.description:
The minimum version of the SSL protocol that
you want CloudFront to use for HTTPS connections. One of SSLv3, TLSv1,
TLSv1_2016, TLSv1.1_2016 or TLSv1.2_2018. Default: TLSv1. NOTE:
If you are using a custom certificate (specified with acm_certificate_arn
or iam_certificate_id), and have specified sni-only in
ssl_support_method, TLSv1 or later must be specified. If you have
specified vip in ssl_support_method, only SSLv3 or TLSv1 can be
specified. If you have specified cloudfront_default_certificate, TLSv1
must be specified.

args.name: ssl_support_method
args.description:
: Specifies how you want CloudFront to serve HTTPS
requests. One of vip or snionly. Required if you specify
acm_certificate_arn or iam_certificate_id. NOTE: vip causes
CloudFront to use a dedicated IP address and may incur extra charges.

args.name: web_acl_id
args.description:
(Optional)  If you're using AWS WAF to filter CloudFront
requests, the Id of the AWS WAF web ACL that is associated with the
distribution.

args.name: retain_on_delete
args.description:
(Optional)  Disables the distribution instead of
deleting it when destroying the resource through Terraform. If this is set,
the distribution needs to be deleted manually afterwards. Default: false.

args.name: cookies
args.description:
(Required)  The forwarded values cookies
that specifies how CloudFront handles cookies (maximum one).

args.name: forward
args.description:
(Required)  Specifies whether you want CloudFront to forward
cookies to the origin that is associated with this cache behavior. You can
specify all, none or whitelist. If whitelist, you must include the
subsequent whitelisted_names

args.name: whitelisted_names
args.description:
(Optional)  If you have specified whitelist to
forward, the whitelisted cookies that you want CloudFront to forward to
your origin.

args.name: headers
args.description:
(Optional)  Specifies the Headers, if any, that you want
CloudFront to vary upon for this cache behavior. Specify * to include all
headers.

args.name: query_string
args.description:
(Required)  Indicates whether you want CloudFront to forward
query strings to the origin that is associated with this cache behavior.

args.name: query_string_cache_keys
args.description:
(Optional)  When specified, along with a value of
true for query_string, all query strings are forwarded, however only the
query string keys listed in this argument are cached. When omitted with a
value of true for query_string, all query string keys are cached.

args.name: event_type
args.description:
(Required)  The specific event to trigger this function.
Valid values: viewer-request, origin-request, viewer-response,
origin-response

args.name: lambda_arn
args.description: (Required)  ARN of the Lambda function.

args.name: locations
args.description:
(Optional)  The ISO 3166-1-alpha-2 codes for which you
want CloudFront either to distribute your content (whitelist) or not
distribute your content (blacklist).

args.name: restriction_type
args.description:
(Required)  The method that you want to use to restrict
distribution of your content by country: none, whitelist, or
blacklist.

args.name: id
args.description: The identifier for the distribution. For example: EDFDVBD632BHDS5.

args.name: arn
args.description: The ARN (Amazon Resource Name) for the distribution. For example: arn:aws:cloudfront::123456789012:distribution/EDFDVBD632BHDS5, where 123456789012 is your AWS account ID.

args.name: caller_reference
args.description:
Internal value used by CloudFront to allow future
updates to the distribution configuration.

args.name: status
args.description:
The current status of the distribution. Deployed if the
distribution's information is fully propagated throughout the Amazon
CloudFront system.

args.name: active_trusted_signers
args.description:
The key pair IDs that CloudFront is aware of for
each trusted signer, if the distribution is set up to serve private content
with signed URLs.

args.name: domain_name
args.description:
The domain name corresponding to the distribution. For
example: d604721fxaaqy9.cloudfront.net.

args.name: last_modified_time
args.description: The date and time the distribution was last modified.

args.name: in_progress_validation_batches
args.description:
The number of invalidation batches
currently in progress.

args.name: etag
args.description:
The current version of the distribution's information. For example:
E2QWRUHAPOMQZL.

args.name: hosted_zone_id
args.description:
The CloudFront Route 53 zone ID that can be used to
 route an Alias Resource Record Set to. This attribute is simply an
 alias for the zone ID Z2FDTNDATAQYW2.

args.name: comment
args.description: (Optional)  An optional comment for the origin access identity.

args.name: id
args.description: The identifier for the distribution. For example: EDFDVBD632BHDS5.

args.name: caller_reference
args.description:
Internal value used by CloudFront to allow future
 updates to the origin access identity.

args.name: cloudfront_access_identity_path
args.description:
A shortcut to the full path for the
 origin access identity to use in CloudFront, see below.

args.name: etag
args.description:
The current version of the origin access identity's information.
 For example: E2QWRUHAPOMQZL.

args.name: iam_arn
args.description:
A pre-generated ARN for use in S3 bucket policies (see below).
 Example: arn:aws:iam::cloudfront:user/CloudFront Origin Access Identity
 E2QWRUHAPOMQZL.

args.name: s3_canonical_user_id
args.description:
The Amazon S3 canonical user ID for the origin
 access identity, which you use when giving the origin access identity read
 permission to an object in Amazon S3.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) Specifies the name of the trail.

args.name: s3_bucket_name
args.description: (Required) Specifies the name of the S3 bucket designated for publishing log files.

args.name: s3_key_prefix
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies the S3 key prefix that precedes
  the name of the bucket you have designated for log file delivery.

args.name: cloud_watch_logs_role_arn
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies the role for the CloudWatch Logs
  endpoint to assume to write to a user’s log group.

args.name: cloud_watch_logs_group_arn
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies a log group name using an Amazon Resource Name (ARN),
  that represents the log group to which CloudTrail logs will be delivered.

args.name: enable_logging
args.description:
(Optional) Enables logging for the trail. Defaults to true.
  Setting this to false will pause logging.

args.name: include_global_service_events
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies whether the trail is publishing events
  from global services such as IAM to the log files. Defaults to true.

args.name: is_multi_region_trail
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies whether the trail is created in the current
  region or in all regions. Defaults to false.

args.name: sns_topic_name
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies the name of the Amazon SNS topic
  defined for notification of log file delivery.

args.name: enable_log_file_validation
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies whether log file integrity validation is enabled.
  Defaults to false.

args.name: kms_key_id
args.description: (Optional) Specifies the KMS key ARN to use to encrypt the logs delivered by CloudTrail.

args.name: event_selector
args.description: (Optional) Specifies the event selector. Fields documented below.

args.name: read_write_type
args.description: (Optional)  Specify if you want your trail to log read-only events, write-only events, or all. By default, the value is All. You can specify only the following value: "ReadOnly", "WriteOnly", "All". Defaults to All.

args.name: include_management_events
args.description: (Optional)  Specify if you want your event selector to include management events for your trail.

args.name: data_resource
args.description: (Optional)  Specifies logging data events. Fields documented below.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the trail

args.name: type
args.description: (Required)  The resource type in witch you want to log data events. You can specify only the follwing value: "AWS::S3::Object", "AWS::Lambda::Function"

args.name: values
args.description: (Required)  A list of ARN for the specified S3 buckets and object prefixes..

args.name: id
args.description: The name of the trail.

args.name: home_region
args.description: The region in which the trail was created.

args.name: arn
args.description: The Amazon Resource Name of the trail.

args.name: dashboard_name
args.description: (Required) The name of the dashboard.

args.name: dashboard_body
args.description: (Required) The detailed information about the dashboard, including what widgets are included and their location on the dashboard. You can read more about the body structure in the documentation.

args.name: dashboard_arn
args.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the dashboard.

args.name: principal
args.description: (Required) The 12-digit AWS account ID that you are permitting to put events to your default event bus. Specify * to permit any account to put events to your default event bus.

args.name: statement_id
args.description: (Required) An identifier string for the external account that you are granting permissions to.

args.name: action
args.description: (Optional) The action that you are enabling the other account to perform. Defaults to events:PutEvents.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The statement ID of the CloudWatch Events permission.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The rule's name.

args.name: schedule_expression
args.description:
(Required, if event_pattern isn't specified) The scheduling expression.
  For example, cron(0 20 * * ? *) or rate(5 minutes).

args.name: event_pattern
args.description:
(Required, if schedule_expression isn't specified) Event pattern
  described a JSON object.
  See full documentation of CloudWatch Events and Event Patterns for details.

args.name: description
args.description: (Optional) The description of the rule.

args.name: role_arn
args.description: (Optional) The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) associated with the role that is used for target invocation.

args.name: is_enabled
args.description: (Optional) Whether the rule should be enabled (defaults to true).

attrs.name: arn
attrs.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the rule.

args.name: rule
args.description: (Required) The name of the rule you want to add targets to.

args.name: target_id
args.description: (Optional) The unique target assignment ID.  If missing, will generate a random, unique id.

args.name: arn
args.description: (Required) The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) associated of the target.

args.name: input
args.description: (Optional) Valid JSON text passed to the target.

args.name: input_paths
args.description: (Optional) Key value pairs specified in the form of JSONPath (for example, time = $.time)

args.name: input_template
args.description: (Required) Structure containing the template body.

args.name: input_path
args.description:
(Optional) The value of the JSONPath
  that is used for extracting part of the matched event when passing it to the target.

args.name: role_arn
args.description: (Optional) The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role to be used for this target when the rule is triggered. Required if ecs_target is used.

args.name: run_command_targets
args.description: (Optional) Parameters used when you are using the rule to invoke Amazon EC2 Run Command. Documented below. A maximum of 5 are allowed.

args.name: key
args.description: (Required) Can be either tag:tag-key or InstanceIds.

args.name: values
args.description: (Required) If Key is tag:tag-key, Values is a list of tag values. If Key is InstanceIds, Values is a list of Amazon EC2 instance IDs.

args.name: ecs_target
args.description: (Optional) Parameters used when you are using the rule to invoke Amazon ECS Task. Documented below. A maximum of 1 are allowed.

args.name: task_count
args.description: (Optional) The number of tasks to create based on the TaskDefinition. The default is 1.

args.name: task_definition_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the task definition to use if the event target is an Amazon ECS cluster.

args.name: input_transformer
args.description: (Optional) Parameters used when you are providing a custom input to a target based on certain event data.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) A name for the log destination

args.name: role_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of an IAM role that grants Amazon CloudWatch Logs permissions to put data into the target

args.name: target_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the target Amazon Kinesis stream or Amazon Lambda resource for the destination

attrs.name: arn
attrs.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) specifying the log destination.

args.name: destination_name
args.description: (Required) A name for the subscription filter

args.name: access_policy
args.description: (Required) The policy document. This is a JSON formatted string.

args.name: name
args.description: (Optional, Forces new resource) The name of the log group. If omitted, Terraform will assign a random, unique name.

args.name: name_prefix
args.description: (Optional, Forces new resource) Creates a unique name beginning with the specified prefix. Conflicts with name.

args.name: retention_in_days
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies the number of days
you want to retain log events in the specified log group.

args.name: kms_key_id
args.description:
(Optional) The ARN of the KMS Key to use when encrypting log data. Please note, after the AWS KMS CMK is disassociated from the log group,
AWS CloudWatch Logs stops encrypting newly ingested data for the log group. All previously ingested data remains encrypted, and AWS CloudWatch Logs requires
permissions for the CMK whenever the encrypted data is requested.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.

attrs.name: arn
attrs.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) specifying the log group.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) A name for the metric filter.

args.name: pattern
args.description:
(Required) A valid CloudWatch Logs filter pattern
for extracting metric data out of ingested log events.

args.name: log_group_name
args.description: (Required) The name of the log group to associate the metric filter with.

args.name: metric_transformation
args.description:
(Required) A block defining collection of information
  needed to define how metric data gets emitted. See below.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the CloudWatch metric to which the monitored log information should be published (e.g. ErrorCount)

args.name: namespace
args.description: (Required) The destination namespace of the CloudWatch metric.

args.name: value
args.description: (Required) What to publish to the metric. For example, if you're counting the occurrences of a particular term like "Error", the value will be "1" for each occurrence. If you're counting the bytes transferred the published value will be the value in the log event.

args.name: default_value
args.description: (Optional) The value to emit when a filter pattern does not match a log event.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The name of the metric filter.

args.name: policy_document
args.description: (Required) Details of the resource policy, including the identity of the principal that is enabled to put logs to this account. This is formatted as a JSON string. Maximum length of 5120 characters.

args.name: policy_name
args.description: (Required) Name of the resource policy.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The name of the CloudWatch log resource policy

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the log stream. Must not be longer than 512 characters and must not contain :

args.name: log_group_name
args.description: (Required) The name of the log group under which the log stream is to be created.

attrs.name: arn
attrs.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) specifying the log stream.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) A name for the subscription filter

args.name: destination_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the destination to deliver matching log events to. Kinesis stream or Lambda function ARN.

args.name: filter_pattern
args.description: (Required) A valid CloudWatch Logs filter pattern for subscribing to a filtered stream of log events.

args.name: log_group_name
args.description: (Required) The name of the log group to associate the subscription filter with

args.name: role_arn
args.description: (Optional) The ARN of an IAM role that grants Amazon CloudWatch Logs permissions to deliver ingested log events to the destination. If you use Lambda as a destination, you should skip this argument and use aws_lambda_permission resource for granting access from CloudWatch logs to the destination Lambda function.

args.name: distribution
args.description: (Optional) The method used to distribute log data to the destination. By default log data is grouped by log stream, but the grouping can be set to random for a more even distribution. This property is only applicable when the destination is an Amazon Kinesis stream. Valid values are "Random" and "ByLogStream".

args.name: alarm_name
args.description: (Required) The descriptive name for the alarm. This name must be unique within the user's AWS account

args.name: comparison_operator
args.description: (Required) The arithmetic operation to use when comparing the specified Statistic and Threshold. The specified Statistic value is used as the first operand. Either of the following is supported: GreaterThanOrEqualToThreshold, GreaterThanThreshold, LessThanThreshold, LessThanOrEqualToThreshold.

args.name: evaluation_periods
args.description: (Required) The number of periods over which data is compared to the specified threshold.

args.name: metric_name
args.description:
(Required) The name for the alarm's associated metric.
See docs for supported metrics.

args.name: namespace
args.description:
(Required) The namespace for the alarm's associated metric. See docs for the list of namespaces.
See docs for supported metrics.

args.name: period
args.description: (Required) The period in seconds over which the specified statistic is applied.

args.name: statistic
args.description:
(Optional) The statistic to apply to the alarm's associated metric.
 Either of the following is supported: SampleCount, Average, Sum, Minimum, Maximum

args.name: threshold
args.description: (Required) The value against which the specified statistic is compared.

args.name: actions_enabled
args.description: (Optional) Indicates whether or not actions should be executed during any changes to the alarm's state. Defaults to true.

args.name: alarm_actions
args.description: (Optional) The list of actions to execute when this alarm transitions into an ALARM state from any other state. Each action is specified as an Amazon Resource Number (ARN).

args.name: alarm_description
args.description: (Optional) The description for the alarm.

args.name: datapoints_to_alarm
args.description: (Optional) The number of datapoints that must be breaching to trigger the alarm.

args.name: dimensions
args.description: (Optional) The dimensions for the alarm's associated metric.  For the list of available dimensions see the AWS documentation here.

args.name: insufficient_data_actions
args.description: (Optional) The list of actions to execute when this alarm transitions into an INSUFFICIENT_DATA state from any other state. Each action is specified as an Amazon Resource Number (ARN).

args.name: ok_actions
args.description: (Optional) The list of actions to execute when this alarm transitions into an OK state from any other state. Each action is specified as an Amazon Resource Number (ARN).

args.name: unit
args.description: (Optional) The unit for the alarm's associated metric.

args.name: extended_statistic
args.description: (Optional) The percentile statistic for the metric associated with the alarm. Specify a value between p0.0 and p100.

args.name: treat_missing_data
args.description: (Optional) Sets how this alarm is to handle missing data points. The following values are supported: missing, ignore, breaching and notBreaching. Defaults to missing.

args.name: evaluate_low_sample_count_percentiles
args.description:
(Optional) Used only for alarms
based on percentiles. If you specify ignore, the alarm state will not
change during periods with too few data points to be statistically significant.
If you specify evaluate or omit this parameter, the alarm will always be
evaluated and possibly change state no matter how many data points are available.
The following values are supported: ignore, and evaluate.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ID of the health check

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The projects name.

args.name: description
args.description: (Optional) A short description of the project.

args.name: encryption_key
args.description: (Optional) The AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) to be used for encrypting the build project's build output artifacts.

args.name: service_role
args.description: (Optional) The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role that enables AWS CodeBuild to interact with dependent AWS services on behalf of the AWS account.

args.name: build_timeout
args.description: (Optional) How long in minutes, from 5 to 480 (8 hours), for AWS CodeBuild to wait until timing out any related build that does not get marked as completed. The default is 60 minutes.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.

args.name: artifacts
args.description: (Required) Information about the project's build output artifacts. Artifact blocks are documented below.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The build output artifact's type. Valid values for this parameter are: CODEPIPELINE, NO_ARTIFACTS or S3.

args.name: location
args.description: (Optional) Information about the build output artifact location. If type is set to CODEPIPELINE or NO_ARTIFACTS then this value will be ignored. If type is set to S3, this is the name of the output bucket. If path is not also specified, then location can also specify the path of the output artifact in the output bucket.

args.name: name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the project. If type is set to S3, this is the name of the output artifact object

args.name: namespace_type
args.description: (Optional) The namespace to use in storing build artifacts. If type is set to S3, then valid values for this parameter are: BUILD_ID or NONE.

args.name: packaging
args.description: (Optional) The type of build output artifact to create. If type is set to S3, valid values for this parameter are: NONE or ZIP

args.name: path
args.description: (Optional) If type is set to S3, this is the path to the output artifact

args.name: environment
args.description: (Required) Information about the project's build environment. Environment blocks are documented below.

args.name: compute_type
args.description: (Required) Information about the compute resources the build project will use. Available values for this parameter are: BUILD_GENERAL1_SMALL, BUILD_GENERAL1_MEDIUM or BUILD_GENERAL1_LARGE

args.name: image
args.description: (Required) The image identifier of the Docker image to use for this build project (list of Docker images provided by AWS CodeBuild.). You can read more about the AWS curated environment images in the documentation.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The type of build environment to use for related builds. The only valid value is LINUX_CONTAINER.

args.name: privileged_mode
args.description: (Optional) If set to true, enables running the Docker daemon inside a Docker container. Defaults to false.

args.name: environment_variable
args.description: (Optional) A set of environment variables to make available to builds for this build project.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The environment variable's name or key.

args.name: value
args.description: (Required) The environment variable's value.

args.name: source
args.description: (Required) Information about the project's input source code. Source blocks are documented below.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The type of repository that contains the source code to be built. Valid values for this parameter are: CODECOMMIT, CODEPIPELINE, GITHUB, BITBUCKET or S3.

args.name: auth
args.description: (Optional) Information about the authorization settings for AWS CodeBuild to access the source code to be built. Auth blocks are documented below.

args.name: buildspec
args.description: (Optional) The build spec declaration to use for this build project's related builds.

args.name: location
args.description: (Optional) The location of the source code from git or s3.

args.name: vpc_config
args.description: (Optional) Configuration for the builds to run inside a VPC. VPC config blocks are documented below.

args.name: vpc_id
args.description: (Required) The ID of the VPC within which to run builds.

args.name: subnets
args.description: (Required) The subnet IDs within which to run builds.

args.name: security_group_ids
args.description: (Required) The security group IDs to assign to running builds.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The authorization type to use. The only valid value is OAUTH

args.name: resource
args.description: (Optional) The resource value that applies to the specified authorization type.

attrs.name: id

attrs.name: description

attrs.name: encryption_key
attrs.description: The AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) that was used for encrypting the build project's build output artifacts.

attrs.name: name
attrs.description: The projects name.

attrs.name: service_role
attrs.description: The ARN of the IAM service role.

args.name: repository_name
args.description: (Required) The name for the repository. This needs to be less than 100 characters.

args.name: description
args.description: (Optional) The description of the repository. This needs to be less than 1000 characters

args.name: default_branch
args.description: (Optional) The default branch of the repository. The branch specified here needs to exist.

attrs.name: repository_id
attrs.description: The ID of the repository

attrs.name: arn
attrs.description: The ARN of the repository

attrs.name: clone_url_http
attrs.description: The URL to use for cloning the repository over HTTPS.

attrs.name: clone_url_ssh
attrs.description: The URL to use for cloning the repository over SSH.

args.name: repository_name
args.description: (Required) The name for the repository. This needs to be less than 100 characters.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the trigger.

args.name: destination_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the resource that is the target for a trigger. For example, the ARN of a topic in Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS).

args.name: custom_data
args.description: (Optional) Any custom data associated with the trigger that will be included in the information sent to the target of the trigger.

args.name: branches
args.description: (Optional) The branches that will be included in the trigger configuration. If no branches are specified, the trigger will apply to all branches.

args.name: events
args.description: (Required) The repository events that will cause the trigger to run actions in another service, such as sending a notification through Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS). If no events are specified, the trigger will run for all repository events. Event types include: all, updateReference, createReference, deleteReference.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the application.

args.name: id
args.description: Amazon's assigned ID for the application.

args.name: name
args.description: The application's name.

args.name: deployment_config_name
args.description: (Required) The name of the deployment config.

args.name: minimum_healthy_hosts
args.description: (Optional) A minimum_healthy_hosts block. Minimum Healthy Hosts are documented below.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The type can either be FLEET_PERCENT or HOST_COUNT.

args.name: value
args.description:
(Required) The value when the type is FLEET_PERCENT represents the minimum number of healthy instances as
a percentage of the total number of instances in the deployment. If you specify FLEET_PERCENT, at the start of the
deployment, AWS CodeDeploy converts the percentage to the equivalent number of instance and rounds up fractional instances.
When the type is HOST_COUNT, the value represents the minimum number of healthy instances as an absolute value.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The deployment group's config name.

attrs.name: deployment_config_id
attrs.description: The AWS Assigned deployment config id

args.name: app_name
args.description: (Required) The name of the application.

args.name: deployment_group_name
args.description: (Required) The name of the deployment group.

args.name: service_role_arn
args.description: (Required) The service role ARN that allows deployments.

args.name: autoscaling_groups
args.description: (Optional) Autoscaling groups associated with the deployment group.

args.name: deployment_config_name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the group's deployment config. The default is "CodeDeployDefault.OneAtATime".

args.name: ec2_tag_filter
args.description: (Optional) Tag filters associated with the group. See the AWS docs for details.

args.name: key
args.description: (Optional) The key of the tag filter.

args.name: type
args.description: (Optional) The type of the tag filter, either KEY_ONLY, VALUE_ONLY, or KEY_AND_VALUE.

args.name: value
args.description: (Optional) The value of the tag filter.

args.name: on_premises_instance_tag_filter
args.description: (Optional) On premise tag filters associated with the group. See the AWS docs for details.

args.name: trigger_configuration
args.description: (Optional) Trigger Configurations for the deployment group (documented below).

args.name: trigger_events
args.description: (Required) The event type or types for which notifications are triggered. Some values that are supported: DeploymentStart, DeploymentSuccess, DeploymentFailure, DeploymentStop, DeploymentRollback, InstanceStart, InstanceSuccess, InstanceFailure.  See the CodeDeploy documentation for all possible values.

args.name: trigger_name
args.description: (Required) The name of the notification trigger.

args.name: trigger_target_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the SNS topic through which notifications are sent.

args.name: auto_rollback_configuration
args.description: (Optional) The automatic rollback configuration associated with the deployment group (documented below).

args.name: enabled
args.description: (Optional) Indicates whether a defined automatic rollback configuration is currently enabled for this Deployment Group. If you enable automatic rollback, you must specify at least one event type.

args.name: events
args.description: (Optional) The event type or types that trigger a rollback. Supported types are DEPLOYMENT_FAILURE and DEPLOYMENT_STOP_ON_ALARM.

args.name: alarm_configuration
args.description: (Optional) Information about alarms associated with the deployment group (documented below).

args.name: alarms
args.description: (Optional) A list of alarms configured for the deployment group. A maximum of 10 alarms can be added to a deployment group.

args.name: enabled
args.description: (Optional) Indicates whether the alarm configuration is enabled. This option is useful when you want to temporarily deactivate alarm monitoring for a deployment group without having to add the same alarms again later.

args.name: true
args.description: : The deployment will proceed even if alarm status information can't be retrieved.

args.name: false
args.description: : The deployment will stop if alarm status information can't be retrieved.

args.name: ignore_poll_alarm_failure
args.description:
(Optional) Indicates whether a deployment should continue if information about the current state of alarms cannot be retrieved from CloudWatch. The default value is false.
true: The deployment will proceed even if alarm status information can't be retrieved.
false: The deployment will stop if alarm status information can't be retrieved.

args.name: deployment_style
args.description: (Optional) Information about the type of deployment, either in-place or blue/green, you want to run and whether to route deployment traffic behind a load balancer (documented below).

args.name: deployment_option
args.description: (Optional) Indicates whether to route deployment traffic behind a load balancer. Valid Values are WITH_TRAFFIC_CONTROL or WITHOUT_TRAFFIC_CONTROL.

args.name: deployment_type
args.description: (Optional) Indicates whether to run an in-place deployment or a blue/green deployment. Valid Values are IN_PLACE or BLUE_GREEN.

args.name: load_balancer_info
args.description: (Optional) Information about the load balancer to use in a blue/green deployment (documented below).

args.name: elb_info
args.description: (Optional) The load balancer to use in a deployment.

args.name: target_group_info
args.description: (Optional) The target group to use in a deployment.

args.name: blue_green_deployment_config
args.description: (Optional) Information about blue/green deployment options for a deployment group (documented below).

args.name: deployment_ready_option
args.description: (Optional) Information about the action to take when newly provisioned instances are ready to receive traffic in a blue/green deployment (documented below).

args.name: green_fleet_provisioning_option
args.description: (Optional) Information about how instances are provisioned for a replacement environment in a blue/green deployment (documented below).

args.name: terminate_blue_instances_on_deployment_success
args.description: (Optional) Information about whether to terminate instances in the original fleet during a blue/green deployment (documented below).

args.name: name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the load balancer that will be used to route traffic from original instances to replacement instances in a blue/green deployment. For in-place deployments, the name of the load balancer that instances are deregistered from so they are not serving traffic during a deployment, and then re-registered with after the deployment completes.

args.name: name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the target group that instances in the original environment are deregistered from, and instances in the replacement environment registered with. For in-place deployments, the name of the target group that instances are deregistered from, so they are not serving traffic during a deployment, and then re-registered with after the deployment completes.

args.name: action_on_timeout
args.description:
(Optional) When to reroute traffic from an original environment to a replacement environment in a blue/green deployment.

CONTINUE_DEPLOYMENT: Register new instances with the load balancer immediately after the new application revision is installed on the instances in the replacement environment.
STOP_DEPLOYMENT: Do not register new instances with load balancer unless traffic is rerouted manually. If traffic is not rerouted manually before the end of the specified wait period, the deployment status is changed to Stopped.

args.name: wait_time_in_minutes
args.description: (Optional) The number of minutes to wait before the status of a blue/green deployment changed to Stopped if rerouting is not started manually. Applies only to the STOP_DEPLOYMENT option for action_on_timeout.

args.name: action
args.description:
(Optional) The method used to add instances to a replacement environment.

DISCOVER_EXISTING: Use instances that already exist or will be created manually.
COPY_AUTO_SCALING_GROUP: Use settings from a specified Auto Scaling group to define and create instances in a new Auto Scaling group. Exactly one Auto Scaling group must be specifed when selecting COPY_AUTO_SCALING_GROUP. Use autoscaling_groups to specify the Auto Scaling group.

args.name: action
args.description:
(Optional) The action to take on instances in the original environment after a successful blue/green deployment.

TERMINATE: Instances are terminated after a specified wait time.

KEEP_ALIVE: Instances are left running after they are deregistered from the load balancer and removed from the deployment group.

args.name: termination_wait_time_in_minutes
args.description: (Optional) The number of minutes to wait after a successful blue/green deployment before terminating instances from the original environment.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the pipeline.

args.name: role_arn
args.description: (Required) A service role Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that grants AWS CodePipeline permission to make calls to AWS services on your behalf.

args.name: artifact_store
args.description: (Required) An artifact_store block. Artifact stores are documented below.

args.name: location
args.description: (Required) The location where AWS CodePipeline stores artifacts for a pipeline, such as an S3 bucket.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The type of the artifact store, such as Amazon S3

args.name: encryption_key
args.description: (Optional) The encryption key block AWS CodePipeline uses to encrypt the data in the artifact store, such as an AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) key. If you don't specify a key, AWS CodePipeline uses the default key for Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3). An encryption_key block is documented below.

args.name: stage
args.description: (Required) A stage block. Stages are documented below.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the stage.

args.name: action
args.description: (Required) The action(s) to include in the stage. Defined as an action block below

args.name: id
args.description: (Required) The KMS key ARN or ID

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The type of key; currently only KMS is supported

args.name: category
args.description: (Required) A category defines what kind of action can be taken in the stage, and constrains the provider type for the action. Possible values are Approval, Build, Deploy, Invoke, Source and Test.

args.name: owner
args.description: (Required) The creator of the action being called. Possible values are AWS, Custom and ThirdParty.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The action declaration's name.

args.name: provider
args.description: (Required) The provider of the service being called by the action. Valid providers are determined by the action category. For example, an action in the Deploy category type might have a provider of AWS CodeDeploy, which would be specified as CodeDeploy.

args.name: version
args.description: (Required) A string that identifies the action type.

args.name: configuration
args.description: (Optional) A Map of the action declaration's configuration. Find out more about configuring action configurations in the Reference Pipeline Structure documentation.

args.name: input_artifacts
args.description: (Optional) A list of artifact names to be worked on.

args.name: output_artifacts
args.description: (Optional) A list of artifact names to output. Output artifact names must be unique within a pipeline.

args.name: role_arn
args.description: (Optional) The ARN of the IAM service role that will perform the declared action. This is assumed through the roleArn for the pipeline.

args.name: run_order
args.description: (Optional) The order in which actions are run.

backend and the Cognito service to communicate about the developer provider.

args.name: provider_name

args.description: (Optional)  Whether server-side token validation is enabled for the identity provider’s token or not.

args.name: saml_provider_arns
args.description: (Optional)  An array of Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) of the SAML provider for your identity.

args.name: role_mapping

args.name: ambiguous_role_resolution
args.description: (Optional)  Specifies the action to be taken if either no rules match the claim value for the Rules type, or there is no cognito:preferred_role claim and there are multiple cognito:roles matches for the Token type. Required if you specify Token or Rules as the Type.

args.name: mapping_rule
args.description: (Optional)  The Rules Configuration to be used for mapping users to roles. You can specify up to 25 rules per identity provider. Rules are evaluated in order. The first one to match specifies the role.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required)  The role mapping type.

args.name: roles
args.description: (Required)  The map of roles associated with this pool. For a given role, the key will be either "authenticated" or "unauthenticated" and the value will be the Role ARN.

args.name: claim
args.description: (Required)  The claim name that must be present in the token, for example, "isAdmin" or "paid".

args.name: match_type
args.description: (Required)  The match condition that specifies how closely the claim value in the IdP token must match Value.

args.name: role_arn
args.description: (Required)  The role ARN.

args.name: value
args.description: (Required)  A brief string that the claim must match, for example, "paid" or "yes".

args.name: owner
args.description:
(Required) Indicates whether AWS or the customer owns and manages the AWS Config rule.
  The only valid value is AWS or CUSTOM_LAMBDA. Keep in mind that Lambda function will require aws_lambda_permission to allow AWSConfig to execute the function.

args.name: source_identifier
args.description:
(Required) For AWS Config managed rules, a predefined identifier from a list. For example,
  IAM_PASSWORD_POLICY is a managed rule. To reference a managed rule, see Using AWS Managed Config Rules.
  For custom rules, the identifier is the ARN of the rule's AWS Lambda function, such as arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:123456789012:function:custom_rule_name.

args.name: event_source
args.description:
(Optional) The source of the event, such as an AWS service, that triggers AWS Config
  to evaluate your AWS resources. This defaults to aws.config and is the only valid value.

args.name: maximum_execution_frequency
args.description:
(Optional) The frequency that you want AWS Config to run evaluations for a rule that
  is triggered periodically. If specified, requires message_type to be ScheduledNotification.

args.name: message_type
args.description:
(Optional) The type of notification that triggers AWS Config to run an evaluation for a rule. You can specify the following notification types:
ConfigurationItemChangeNotification - Triggers an evaluation when AWS
  Config delivers a configuration item as a result of a resource change.
OversizedConfigurationItemChangeNotification - Triggers an evaluation
  when AWS Config delivers an oversized configuration item. AWS Config may
  generate this notification type when a resource changes and the notification
  exceeds the maximum size allowed by Amazon SNS.
ScheduledNotification - Triggers a periodic evaluation at the frequency
  specified for maximum_execution_frequency.
ConfigurationSnapshotDeliveryCompleted - Triggers a periodic evaluation
  when AWS Config delivers a configuration snapshot.

args.name: source_detail
args.description:
(Optional) Provides the source and type of the event that causes AWS Config to evaluate your AWS resources. Only valid if owner is CUSTOM_LAMBDA.
event_source - (Optional) The source of the event, such as an AWS service, that triggers AWS Config
  to evaluate your AWS resources. This defaults to aws.config and is the only valid value.
maximum_execution_frequency - (Optional) The frequency that you want AWS Config to run evaluations for a rule that
  is triggered periodically. If specified, requires message_type to be ScheduledNotification.
message_type - (Optional) The type of notification that triggers AWS Config to run an evaluation for a rule. You can specify the following notification types:
ConfigurationItemChangeNotification - Triggers an evaluation when AWS
  Config delivers a configuration item as a result of a resource change.
OversizedConfigurationItemChangeNotification - Triggers an evaluation
  when AWS Config delivers an oversized configuration item. AWS Config may
  generate this notification type when a resource changes and the notification
  exceeds the maximum size allowed by Amazon SNS.
ScheduledNotification - Triggers a periodic evaluation at the frequency
  specified for maximum_execution_frequency.
ConfigurationSnapshotDeliveryCompleted - Triggers a periodic evaluation
  when AWS Config delivers a configuration snapshot.

attrs.description: The ARN of the config rule

args.name: name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the recorder. Defaults to default. Changing it recreates the resource.

args.name: role_arn
args.description:
(Required) Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role.
  used to make read or write requests to the delivery channel and to describe the AWS resources associated with the account.
  See AWS Docs for more details.

args.name: recording_group
args.description: (Optional) Recording group - see below.

args.name: all_supported
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies whether AWS Config records configuration changes
  for every supported type of regional resource (which includes any new type that will become supported in the future).
  Conflicts with resource_types. Defaults to true.

args.name: include_global_resource_types
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies whether AWS Config includes all supported types of global resources
  with the resources that it records. Requires all_supported = true. Conflicts with resource_types.

args.name: resource_types
args.description:
(Optional) A list that specifies the types of AWS resources for which
  AWS Config records configuration changes (for example, AWS::EC2::Instance or AWS::CloudTrail::Trail).
See relevant part of AWS Docs for available types.

If you do not specify a value for kms_key_arn, then AWS DMS will use your default encryption key. AWS KMS creates the default encryption key for your AWS account. Your AWS account has a different default encryption key for each AWS region.

args.name: apply_immediately
args.description: (Optional, Default: false) Indicates whether the changes should be applied immediately or during the next maintenance window. Only used when updating an existing resource.

args.name: auto_minor_version_upgrade
args.description: (Optional, Default: false) Indicates that minor engine upgrades will be applied automatically to the replication instance during the maintenance window.

args.name: availability_zone
args.description: (Optional) The EC2 Availability Zone that the replication instance will be created in.

args.name: engine_version
args.description: (Optional) The engine version number of the replication instance.

args.name: kms_key_arn
args.description: (Optional) The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the KMS key that will be used to encrypt the connection parameters. If you do not specify a value for kms_key_arn, then AWS DMS will use your default encryption key. AWS KMS creates the default encryption key for your AWS account. Your AWS account has a different default encryption key for each AWS region.

args.name: multi_az
args.description: (Optional) Specifies if the replication instance is a multi-az deployment. You cannot set the availability_zone parameter if the multi_az parameter is set to true.

args.name: preferred_maintenance_window
args.description:
(Optional) The weekly time range during which system maintenance can occur, in Universal Coordinated Time (UTC).

Default: A 30-minute window selected at random from an 8-hour block of time per region, occurring on a random day of the week.
Format: ddd:hh24:mi-ddd:hh24:mi
Valid Days: mon, tue, wed, thu, fri, sat, sun
Constraints: Minimum 30-minute window.

args.name: publicly_accessible

args.description: (Required) The compute and memory capacity of the replication instance as specified by the replication instance class. Can be one of dms.t2.micro | dms.t2.small | dms.t2.medium | dms.t2.large | dms.c4.large | dms.c4.xlarge | dms.c4.2xlarge | dms.c4.4xlarge

must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens, and must not begin or end with a hyphen. If not specified,
Terraform will autogenerate a name beginning with tf-lb.

args.description: (Optional) If true, the LB will be internal.

(Optional) A list of subnet IDs to attach to the LB. Subnets

args.description: (Optional) The time in seconds that the connection is allowed to be idle. Default: 60.

args.description:
(Optional) If true, deletion of the load balancer will be disabled via

args.description:
(Optional) If true, cross-zone load balancing of the load balancer will be enabled.
 This is a network load balancer feature. Defaults to false.
