attrs.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) specifying the Stream (same as id)

args.name: name
args.description:
(Required) A name to identify the stream. This is unique to the
AWS account and region the Stream is created in.

args.name: kinesis_source_configuration
args.description: (Optional) Allows the ability to specify the kinesis stream that is used as the source of the firehose delivery stream.

args.name: kinesis_stream_arn
args.description: (Required) The kinesis stream used as the source of the firehose delivery stream.

args.name: role_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the role that provides access to the source Kinesis stream.

args.name: destination
args.description: – (Required) This is the destination to where the data is delivered. The only options are s3 (Deprecated, use extended_s3 instead), extended_s3, redshift, and elasticsearch.

args.name: s3_configuration
args.description:
(Optional, Deprecated, see/use extended_s3_configuration unless destination is redshift) Configuration options for the s3 destination (or the intermediate bucket if the destination
is redshift). More details are given below.

args.name: role_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the AWS credentials.

args.name: bucket_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the S3 bucket

args.name: prefix
args.description: (Optional) The "YYYY/MM/DD/HH" time format prefix is automatically used for delivered S3 files. You can specify an extra prefix to be added in front of the time format prefix. Note that if the prefix ends with a slash, it appears as a folder in the S3 bucket

args.name: buffer_size
args.description: (Optional) Buffer incoming data to the specified size, in MBs, before delivering it to the destination. The default value is 5.                          We recommend setting SizeInMBs to a value greater than the amount of data you typically ingest into the delivery stream in 10 seconds. For example, if you typically ingest data at 1 MB/sec set SizeInMBs to be 10 MB or higher.

args.name: buffer_interval
args.description: (Optional) Buffer incoming data for the specified period of time, in seconds, before delivering it to the destination. The default value is 300.

args.name: compression_format
args.description: (Optional) The compression format. If no value is specified, the default is UNCOMPRESSED. Other supported values are GZIP, ZIP & Snappy. If the destination is redshift you cannot use ZIP or Snappy.

args.name: kms_key_arn
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies the KMS key ARN the stream will use to encrypt data. If not set, no encryption will
be used.

args.name: cloudwatch_logging_options
args.description: (Optional) The CloudWatch Logging Options for the delivery stream. More details are given below

args.name: processing_configuration
args.description: (Optional) The data processing configuration.  More details are given below.

args.name: extended_s3_configuration
args.description: (Optional, only Required when destination is extended_s3) Enhanced configuration options for the s3 destination. More details are given below.

args.name: redshift_configuration
args.description:
(Optional) Configuration options if redshift is the destination.
Using redshift_configuration requires the user to also specify a
s3_configuration block. More details are given below.

args.name: cluster_jdbcurl
args.description: (Required) The jdbcurl of the redshift cluster.

args.name: username
args.description: (Required) The username that the firehose delivery stream will assume. It is strongly recommended that the username and password provided is used exclusively for Amazon Kinesis Firehose purposes, and that the permissions for the account are restricted for Amazon Redshift INSERT permissions.

args.name: password
args.description: (Required) The password for the username above.

args.name: retry_duration
args.description: (Optional) The length of time during which Firehose retries delivery after a failure, starting from the initial request and including the first attempt. The default value is 3600 seconds (60 minutes). Firehose does not retry if the value of DurationInSeconds is 0 (zero) or if the first delivery attempt takes longer than the current value.

args.name: role_arn
args.description: (Required) The arn of the role the stream assumes.

args.name: s3_backup_mode
args.description: (Optional) The Amazon S3 backup mode.  Valid values are Disabled and Enabled.  Default value is Disabled.

args.name: s3_backup_configuration
args.description: (Optional) The configuration for backup in Amazon S3. Required if s3_backup_mode is Enabled. Supports the same fields as s3_configuration object.

args.name: data_table_name
args.description: (Required) The name of the table in the redshift cluster that the s3 bucket will copy to.

args.name: copy_options
args.description: (Optional) Copy options for copying the data from the s3 intermediate bucket into redshift, for example to change the default delimiter. For valid values, see the AWS documentation

args.name: data_table_columns
args.description: (Optional) The data table columns that will be targeted by the copy command.

args.name: cloudwatch_logging_options
args.description: (Optional) The CloudWatch Logging Options for the delivery stream. More details are given below

args.name: buffering_interval
args.description: (Optional) Buffer incoming data for the specified period of time, in seconds between 60 to 900, before delivering it to the destination.  The default value is 300s.

args.name: buffering_size
args.description: (Optional) Buffer incoming data to the specified size, in MBs between 1 to 100, before delivering it to the destination.  The default value is 5MB.

args.name: domain_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the Amazon ES domain.  The IAM role must have permission for DescribeElasticsearchDomain, DescribeElasticsearchDomains, and DescribeElasticsearchDomainConfig after assuming RoleARN.  The pattern needs to be arn:.*.

args.name: index_name
args.description: (Required) The Elasticsearch index name.

args.name: index_rotation_period
args.description: (Optional) The Elasticsearch index rotation period.  Index rotation appends a timestamp to the IndexName to facilitate expiration of old data.  Valid values are NoRotation, OneHour, OneDay, OneWeek, and OneMonth.  The default value is OneDay.

args.name: retry_duration
args.description: (Optional) After an initial failure to deliver to Amazon Elasticsearch, the total amount of time, in seconds between 0 to 7200, during which Firehose re-attempts delivery (including the first attempt).  After this time has elapsed, the failed documents are written to Amazon S3.  The default value is 300s.  There will be no retry if the value is 0.

args.name: role_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the IAM role to be assumed by Firehose for calling the Amazon ES Configuration API and for indexing documents.  The pattern needs to be arn:.*.

args.name: s3_backup_mode
args.description: (Optional) Defines how documents should be delivered to Amazon S3.  Valid values are FailedDocumentsOnly and AllDocuments.  Default value is FailedDocumentsOnly.

args.name: type_name
args.description: (Required) The Elasticsearch type name with maximum length of 100 characters.

args.name: cloudwatch_logging_options
args.description: (Optional) The CloudWatch Logging Options for the delivery stream. More details are given below

args.name: enabled
args.description: (Optional) Enables or disables the logging. Defaults to false.

args.name: log_group_name
args.description: (Optional) The CloudWatch group name for logging. This value is required if enabled is true.

args.name: log_stream_name
args.description: (Optional) The CloudWatch log stream name for logging. This value is required if enabled is true.

args.name: hec_acknowledgment_timeout
args.description: (Optional) The amount of time, in seconds between 180 and 600, that Kinesis Firehose waits to receive an acknowledgment from Splunk after it sends it data.

args.name: hec_endpoint
args.description: (Required) The HTTP Event Collector (HEC) endpoint to which Kinesis Firehose sends your data.

args.name: hec_endpoint_type
args.description: (Optional) The HEC endpoint type. Valid values are Raw or Event. The default value is Raw.

args.name: hec_token
args.description: The GUID that you obtain from your Splunk cluster when you create a new HEC endpoint.

args.name: s3_backup_mode
args.description: (Optional) Defines how documents should be delivered to Amazon S3.  Valid values are FailedDocumentsOnly and AllDocuments.  Default value is FailedDocumentsOnly.

args.name: retry_duration
args.description: (Optional) After an initial failure to deliver to Amazon Elasticsearch, the total amount of time, in seconds between 0 to 7200, during which Firehose re-attempts delivery (including the first attempt).  After this time has elapsed, the failed documents are written to Amazon S3.  The default value is 300s.  There will be no retry if the value is 0.

args.name: cloudwatch_logging_options
args.description: (Optional) The CloudWatch Logging Options for the delivery stream. More details are given below.

args.name: enabled
args.description: (Optional) Enables or disables data processing.

args.description: (Optional) Array of data processors. More details are given below

args.name: parameters

args.name: parameter_value
args.description: (Required) Parameter value. Must be between 1 and 512 length (inclusive). When providing a Lambda ARN, you should specify the resource version as well.

args.description: (Optional) The S3 key of an object containing the function's deployment package. Conflicts with filename.

args.name: s3_object_version
args.description: (Optional) The object version containing the function's deployment package. Conflicts with filename.

args.name: function_name
args.description: (Required) A unique name for your Lambda Function.

args.name: dead_letter_config
args.description: (Optional) Nested block to configure the function's dead letter queue. See details below.

args.name: target_arn
args.description:
(Required) The ARN of an SNS topic or SQS queue to notify when an invocation fails. If this
option is used, the function's IAM role must be granted suitable access to write to the target object,
which means allowing either the sns:Publish or sqs:SendMessage action on this ARN, depending on
which service is targeted.

args.name: handler
args.description: (Required) The function entrypoint in your code.

args.name: role
args.description: (Required) IAM role attached to the Lambda Function. This governs both who / what can invoke your Lambda Function, as well as what resources our Lambda Function has access to. See Lambda Permission Model for more details.

args.name: description
args.description: (Optional) Description of what your Lambda Function does.

args.name: memory_size
args.description: (Optional) Amount of memory in MB your Lambda Function can use at runtime. Defaults to 128. See Limits

args.name: runtime
args.description: (Required) See Runtimes for valid values.

args.name: timeout
args.description: (Optional) The amount of time your Lambda Function has to run in seconds. Defaults to 3. See Limits

args.name: reserved_concurrent_executions
args.description: (Optional) The amount of reserved concurrent executions for this lambda function. Defaults to Unreserved Concurrency Limits. See Managing Concurrency

args.name: publish
args.description: (Optional) Whether to publish creation/change as new Lambda Function Version. Defaults to false.

args.name: vpc_config
args.description: (Optional) Provide this to allow your function to access your VPC. Fields documented below. See Lambda in VPC

args.name: subnet_ids
args.description: (Required) A list of subnet IDs associated with the Lambda function.

args.name: security_group_ids
args.description: (Required) A list of security group IDs associated with the Lambda function.

args.name: environment
args.description: (Optional) The Lambda environment's configuration settings. Fields documented below.

args.name: variables
args.description: (Optional) A map that defines environment variables for the Lambda function.

args.name: kms_key_arn
args.description: (Optional) The ARN for the KMS encryption key.

args.name: source_code_hash
args.description: (Optional) Used to trigger updates. Must be set to a base64-encoded SHA256 hash of the package file specified with either filename or s3_key. The usual way to set this is ${base64sha256(file("file.zip"))}, where "file.zip" is the local filename of the lambda function source archive.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the object.

args.name: mode
args.description:
(Required) Can be either PassThrough or Active. If PassThrough, Lambda will only trace
the request from an upstream service if it contains a tracing header with
"sampled=1". If Active, Lambda will respect any tracing header it receives
from an upstream service. If no tracing header is received, Lambda will call
X-Ray for a tracing decision.

attrs.name: arn
attrs.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) identifying your Lambda Function.

attrs.name: qualified_arn
attrs.description:
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) identifying your Lambda Function Version
(if versioning is enabled via publish = true).

attrs.name: invoke_arn
attrs.description: The ARN to be used for invoking Lambda Function from API Gateway - to be used in aws_api_gateway_integration's uri

attrs.name: version
attrs.description: Latest published version of your Lambda Function.

attrs.name: last_modified
attrs.description: The date this resource was last modified.

attrs.name: kms_key_arn
attrs.description: (Optional) The ARN for the KMS encryption key.

attrs.name: source_code_hash
attrs.description:
Base64-encoded representation of raw SHA-256 sum of the zip file
provided either via filename or s3_* parameters.

args.name: action
args.description: (Required) The AWS Lambda action you want to allow in this statement. (e.g. lambda:InvokeFunction)

args.name: function_name
args.description: (Required) Name of the Lambda function whose resource policy you are updating

args.name: principal
args.description:
(Required) The principal who is getting this permission.
  e.g. s3.amazonaws.com, an AWS account ID, or any valid AWS service principal
  such as events.amazonaws.com or sns.amazonaws.com.

args.name: statement_id
args.description: (Required) A unique statement identifier.

args.name: qualifier
args.description:
(Optional) Query parameter to specify function version or alias name.
  The permission will then apply to the specific qualified ARN.
  e.g. arn:aws:lambda:aws-region:acct-id:function:function-name:2

args.name: source_account
args.description: (Optional) This parameter is used for S3 and SES. The AWS account ID (without a hyphen) of the source owner.

args.name: source_arn
args.description:
(Optional) When granting Amazon S3 or CloudWatch Events permission to
  invoke your function, you should specify this field with the Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
  for the S3 Bucket or CloudWatch Events Rule as its value.  This ensures that only events
  generated from the specified bucket or rule can invoke the function.
  API Gateway ARNs have a unique structure described
  here.

args.name: domain_name

args.name: bundle_id

attrs.name: arn

attrs.name: fingerprint
attrs.description: The MD5 public key fingerprint as specified in section 4 of RFC 4716.

attrs.name: private_key

the private key, base64 encoded. This is only populated

encrypted with the given pgp_key. This is only populated when creating a new

The MD5 public key fingerprint for the encrypted
private key

args.name: apply_immediately
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies whether any broker modifications
are applied immediately, or during the next maintenance window. Default is false.

args.name: auto_minor_version_upgrade
args.description: (Optional) Enables automatic upgrades to new minor versions for brokers, as Apache releases the versions.

args.name: broker_name
args.description: (Required) The name of the broker.

args.name: configuration
args.description: (Optional) Configuration of the broker. See below.

args.name: id
args.description: (Optional) The Configuration ID.

args.name: revision
args.description: (Optional) Revision of the Configuration.

args.name: deployment_mode
args.description: (Optional) The deployment mode of the broker. Supported: SINGLE_INSTANCE and ACTIVE_STANDBY_MULTI_AZ. Defaults to SINGLE_INSTANCE.

args.name: engine_type
args.description: (Required) The type of broker engine. Currently, Amazon MQ supports only ActiveMQ.

args.name: engine_version
args.description: (Required) The version of the broker engine. Currently, Amazon MQ supports only 5.15.0.

args.name: host_instance_type
args.description: (Required) The broker's instance type. e.g. mq.t2.micro or mq.m4.large

args.name: publicly_accessible
args.description: (Optional) Whether to enable connections from applications outside of the VPC that hosts the broker's subnets.

args.name: security_groups
args.description: (Required) The list of security group IDs assigned to the broker.

args.name: subnet_ids
args.description: (Optional) The list of subnet IDs in which to launch the broker. A SINGLE_INSTANCE deployment requires one subnet. An ACTIVE_STANDBY_MULTI_AZ deployment requires two subnets.

args.name: maintenance_window_start_time
args.description: (Optional) Maintenance window start time. See below.

args.name: day_of_week
args.description: (Required) The day of the week. e.g. MONDAY, TUESDAY, or WEDNESDAY

args.name: time_of_day
args.description: (Required) The time, in 24-hour format. e.g. 02:00

args.name: time_zone
args.description: (Required) The time zone, UTC by default, in either the Country/City format, or the UTC offset format. e.g. CET

args.name: user
args.description: (Optional) The list of all ActiveMQ usernames for the specified broker. See below.

args.name: console_access
args.description: (Optional) Whether to enable access to the the ActiveMQ Web Console for the user.

args.name: groups
args.description: (Optional) The list of groups (20 maximum) to which the ActiveMQ user belongs.

args.name: password
args.description: (Required) The password of the user. It must be 12 to 250 characters long, at least 4 unique characters, and must not contain commas.

args.name: username
args.description: (Required) The username of the user.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The unique ID that Amazon MQ generates for the broker.

attrs.name: arn
attrs.description: The ARN of the broker.

attrs.name: instances
attrs.description:
A list of information about allocated brokers (both active & standby).
instances.0.console_url - The URL of the broker's ActiveMQ Web Console.
instances.0.endpoints - The broker's wire-level protocol endpoints in the following order & format referenceable e.g. as instances.0.endpoints.0 (SSL):
ssl://broker-id.mq.us-west-2.amazonaws.com:61617
amqp+ssl://broker-id.mq.us-west-2.amazonaws.com:5671
stomp+ssl://broker-id.mq.us-west-2.amazonaws.com:61614
mqtt+ssl://broker-id.mq.us-west-2.amazonaws.com:8883
wss://broker-id.mq.us-west-2.amazonaws.com:61619

args.description: (Optional) The desired state of the instance.  Can be either "running" or "stopped".

args.name: install_updates_on_boot
args.description: (Optional) Controls where to install OS and package updates when the instance boots.  Defaults to true.

args.description: (Optional) Creates load-based or time-based instances.  If set, can be either: "load" or "timer".

by default.

args.description: (Optional) If true, the launched EC2 instance will be EBS-optimized.

args.name: hostname
args.description: (Optional) The instance's host name.

args.name: architecture
args.description: (Optional) Machine architecture for created instances.  Can be either "x86_64" (the default) or "i386"

args.name: ami_id
args.description: (Optional) The AMI to use for the instance.  If an AMI is specified, os must be "Custom".

args.name: os
args.description: (Optional) Name of operating system that will be installed.

args.name: root_device_type
args.description: (Optional) Name of the type of root device instances will have by default.  Can be either "ebs" or "instance-store"

args.name: ssh_key_name
args.description: (Optional) Name of the SSH keypair that instances will have by default.

args.name: agent_version

will use. Can be either "paravirtual" or "hvm".

args.name: root_block_device

(Optional) Customize details about the root block
device of the instance. See Block Devices below for details.

args.description:
(Optional) The type of volume. Can be "standard", "gp2",
or "io1". (Default: "standard").

args.name: volume_size
args.description: (Optional) The size of the volume in gigabytes.

args.name: iops
args.description:
(Optional) The amount of provisioned
IOPS.

args.name: delete_on_termination
args.description:
(Optional) Whether the volume should be destroyed
on instance termination (Default: true).

args.name: device_name
args.description: The name of the device to mount.

args.name: snapshot_id
args.description: (Optional) The Snapshot ID to mount.

args.name: volume_type
args.description:
(Optional) The type of volume. Can be "standard", "gp2",
or "io1". (Default: "standard").

args.name: volume_size
args.description: (Optional) The size of the volume in gigabytes.

args.name: iops
args.description:
(Optional) The amount of provisioned
IOPS.
This must be set with a volume_type of "io1".

args.name: delete_on_termination
args.description:
(Optional) Whether the volume should be destroyed
on instance termination (Default: true).

args.name: ephemeral_block_device
args.description:
(Optional) Customize Ephemeral (also known as
"Instance Store") volumes on the instance. See Block Devices below for details.

args.name: device_name
args.description: The name of the block device to mount on the instance.

args.name: virtual_name
args.description:
The Instance Store Device
Name
(e.g. "ephemeral0")

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The id of the OpsWorks instance.

attrs.name: agent_version
attrs.description: The AWS OpsWorks agent version.

attrs.name: availability_zone
attrs.description: The availability zone of the instance.

attrs.name: ssh_key_name
attrs.description: The key name of the instance

attrs.name: public_dns
attrs.description:
The public DNS name assigned to the instance. For EC2-VPC, this
is only available if you've enabled DNS hostnames for your VPC

attrs.name: public_ip
attrs.description: The public IP address assigned to the instance, if applicable.

attrs.name: private_dns
attrs.description:
The private DNS name assigned to the instance. Can only be
used inside the Amazon EC2, and only available if you've enabled DNS hostnames
for your VPC

attrs.name: private_ip
attrs.description: The private IP address assigned to the instance

attrs.name: subnet_id
attrs.description: The VPC subnet ID.

attrs.name: tenancy
attrs.description: The Instance tenancy

attrs.name: security_group_ids
attrs.description: The associated security groups.

args.name: stack_id
args.description: (Required) The id of the stack the layer will belong to.

args.name: name
args.description: (Optional) A human-readable name for the layer.

args.name: app_server
args.description: (Optional) Keyword for the application container to use. Defaults to "tomcat".

args.name: app_server_version
args.description: (Optional) Version of the selected application container to use. Defaults to "7".

args.name: auto_assign_elastic_ips
args.description: (Optional) Whether to automatically assign an elastic IP address to the layer's instances.

args.name: auto_assign_public_ips
args.description: (Optional) For stacks belonging to a VPC, whether to automatically assign a public IP address to each of the layer's instances.

args.name: custom_instance_profile_arn
args.description: (Optional) The ARN of an IAM profile that will be used for the layer's instances.

args.name: custom_security_group_ids
args.description: (Optional) Ids for a set of security groups to apply to the layer's instances.

args.name: auto_healing
args.description: (Optional) Whether to enable auto-healing for the layer.

args.name: install_updates_on_boot
args.description: (Optional) Whether to install OS and package updates on each instance when it boots.

args.name: instance_shutdown_timeout
args.description: (Optional) The time, in seconds, that OpsWorks will wait for Chef to complete after triggering the Shutdown event.

args.name: jvm_type
args.description: (Optional) Keyword for the type of JVM to use. Defaults to openjdk.

args.name: jvm_options
args.description: (Optional) Options to set for the JVM.

args.name: jvm_version
args.description: (Optional) Version of JVM to use. Defaults to "7".

args.name: elastic_load_balancer
args.description: (Optional) Name of an Elastic Load Balancer to attach to this layer

args.name: drain_elb_on_shutdown
args.description: (Optional) Whether to enable Elastic Load Balancing connection draining.

args.name: system_packages
args.description: (Optional) Names of a set of system packages to install on the layer's instances.

args.name: use_ebs_optimized_instances
args.description: (Optional) Whether to use EBS-optimized instances.

args.name: ebs_volume
args.description: (Optional) ebs_volume blocks, as described below, will each create an EBS volume and connect it to the layer's instances.

args.name: mount_point
args.description: (Required) The path to mount the EBS volume on the layer's instances.

args.name: size
args.description: (Required) The size of the volume in gigabytes.

args.name: number_of_disks
args.description: (Required) The number of disks to use for the EBS volume.

args.name: raid_level
args.description: (Required) The RAID level to use for the volume.

args.name: type
args.description: (Optional) The type of volume to create. This may be standard (the default), io1 or gp2.

args.name: iops
args.description: (Optional) For PIOPS volumes, the IOPS per disk.

args.name: custom_json
args.description: (Optional) Custom JSON attributes to apply to the layer.

args.description: (Required) The name of the stack.

args.description: (Required) The name of the region where the stack will exist.

args.description: (Required) The ARN of an IAM role that the OpsWorks service will act as.

args.description:
(Required) The ARN of an IAM Instance Profile that created instances
will have by default.

args.description: (Optional) If set to "LATEST", OpsWorks will automatically install the latest version.

args.description: (Optional) Color to paint next to the stack's resources in the OpsWorks console.

args.description: (Optional) Version of the configuration manager to use. Defaults to "11.4".

args.description:

args.name: url
args.description: (Required) The URL where the cookbooks resource can be found.

args.name: username
args.description: (Optional) Username to use when authenticating to the source.

args.name: password
args.description: (Optional) Password to use when authenticating to the source.

args.name: ssh_key
args.description: (Optional) SSH key to use when authenticating to the source.

args.name: revision
args.description: (Optional) For sources that are version-aware, the revision to use.

args.name: custom_json
args.description: (Optional) User defined JSON passed to "Chef". Use a "here doc" for multiline JSON.

args.name: default_os
args.description: (Optional) Name of OS that will be installed on instances by default.

args.name: default_root_device_type
args.description: (Optional) Name of the type of root device instances will have by default.

args.name: default_ssh_key_name
args.description: (Optional) Name of the SSH keypair that instances will have by default.

args.name: default_subnet_id
args.description:
(Optional) Id of the subnet in which instances will be created by default. Mandatory
if vpc_id is set, and forbidden if it isn't.

args.name: hostname_theme
args.description:
(Optional) Keyword representing the naming scheme that will be used for instance hostnames
within this stack.

args.name: manage_berkshelf
args.description: (Optional) Boolean value controlling whether Opsworks will run Berkshelf for this stack.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.

args.name: use_custom_cookbooks
args.description:
(Optional) Boolean value controlling whether the custom cookbook settings are
enabled.

args.name: use_opsworks_security_groups
args.description:
(Optional) Boolean value controlling whether the standard OpsWorks
security groups apply to created instances.

args.name: vpc_id
args.description: (Optional) The id of the VPC that this stack belongs to.

args.name: custom_json
args.description: (Optional) Custom JSON attributes to apply to the entire stack.

args.name: apply_immediately
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies whether any database modifications
are applied immediately, or during the next maintenance window. Default is
false. See Amazon RDS Documentation for more
information.
for more information.

args.name: auto_minor_version_upgrade
args.description:
(Optional) Indicates that minor engine upgrades
will be applied automatically to the DB instance during the maintenance window.
Defaults to true.

args.name: availability_zone
args.description: (Optional) The AZ for the RDS instance.

args.name: backup_retention_period
args.description:
(Optional) The days to retain backups for. Must be
1 or greater to be a source for a [Read Replica][1].

args.name: backup_window
args.description:
(Optional) The daily time range (in UTC) during which
automated backups are created if they are enabled. Example: "09:46-10:16". Must
not overlap with maintenance_window.

args.name: character_set_name
args.description:
(Optional) The character set name to use for DB
encoding in Oracle instances. This can't be changed. See Oracle Character Sets
Supported in Amazon
RDS
for more information.

args.name: copy_tags_to_snapshot
args.description:
– (Optional, boolean) On delete, copy all Instance
tags to the final snapshot (if final_snapshot_identifier is specified).
Default is false.

args.name: db_subnet_group_name
args.description:
(Optional) Name of DB subnet group. DB instance will
be created in the VPC associated with the DB subnet group. If unspecified, will
be created in the default VPC, or in EC2 Classic, if available.

args.name: engine
args.description:
(Required unless a snapshot_identifier or replicate_source_db
is provided) The database engine to use.

args.name: engine_version
args.description: (Optional) The engine version to use.

args.name: final_snapshot_identifier
args.description:
(Optional) The name of your final DB snapshot
when this DB instance is deleted. If omitted, no final snapshot will be made.

args.name: iam_database_authentication_enabled
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies whether or
mappings of AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) accounts to database
accounts is enabled.

args.name: identifier
args.description:
(Optional, Forces new resource) The name of the RDS instance,
if omitted, Terraform will assign a random, unique identifier.

args.name: identifier_prefix
args.description:
(Optional, Forces new resource) Creates a unique
identifier beginning with the specified prefix. Conflicts with identifer.

args.name: instance_class
args.description: (Required) The instance type of the RDS instance.

args.name: iops
args.description:
(Optional) The amount of provisioned IOPS. Setting this implies a
storage_type of "io1".

args.name: kms_key_id
args.description:
(Optional) The ARN for the KMS encryption key. If creating an
encrypted replica, set this to the destination KMS ARN.

args.name: license_model
args.description:
(Optional, but required for some DB engines, i.e. Oracle
SE1) License model information for this DB instance.

args.name: maintenance_window
args.description:
(Optional) The window to perform maintenance in.
Syntax: "ddd:hh24:mi-ddd:hh24:mi". Eg: "Mon:00:00-Mon:03:00". See RDS
Maintenance Window
docs
for more information.

args.name: monitoring_interval
args.description:
(Optional) The interval, in seconds, between points
when Enhanced Monitoring metrics are collected for the DB instance. To disable
collecting Enhanced Monitoring metrics, specify 0. The default is 0. Valid
Values: 0, 1, 5, 10, 15, 30, 60.

args.name: monitoring_role_arn
args.description:
(Optional) The ARN for the IAM role that permits RDS
to send enhanced monitoring metrics to CloudWatch Logs. You can find more
information on the AWS
Documentation
what IAM permissions are needed to allow Enhanced Monitoring for RDS Instances.

args.name: multi_az
args.description: (Optional) Specifies if the RDS instance is multi-AZ

args.name: name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the database to create when the DB instance is created. If this parameter is not specified, no database is created in the DB instance. Note that this does not apply for Oracle or SQL Server engines. See the AWS documentation for more details on what applies for those engines.

args.name: option_group_name
args.description: (Optional) Name of the DB option group to associate.

args.name: parameter_group_name
args.description:
(Optional) Name of the DB parameter group to
associate.

args.name: password
args.description:
(Required unless a snapshot_identifier or replicate_source_db
is provided) Password for the master DB user. Note that this may show up in
logs, and it will be stored in the state file.

args.name: port
args.description: (Optional) The port on which the DB accepts connections.

args.name: publicly_accessible
args.description:
(Optional) Bool to control if instance is publicly
accessible. Default is false.

args.name: replicate_source_db
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies that this resource is a Replicate
database, and to use this value as the source database. This correlates to the
identifier of another Amazon RDS Database to replicate. See [DB Instance
Replication][1] and Working with PostgreSQL and MySQL Read
Replicas
for more information on using Replication.

args.name: security_group_names
args.description:
(Optional/Deprecated) List of DB Security Groups to
associate. Only used for DB Instances on the EC2-Classic
Platform.

args.name: skip_final_snapshot
args.description:
(Optional) Determines whether a final DB snapshot is
created before the DB instance is deleted. If true is specified, no DBSnapshot
is created. If false is specified, a DB snapshot is created before the DB
instance is deleted, using the value from final_snapshot_identifier. Default
is false.

args.name: snapshot_identifier
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies whether or not to create this
database from a snapshot. This correlates to the snapshot ID you'd find in the
RDS console, e.g: rds:production-2015-06-26-06-05.

args.name: storage_encrypted
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies whether the DB instance is
encrypted. The default is false if not specified.

args.name: storage_type
args.description:
(Optional) One of "standard" (magnetic), "gp2" (general
purpose SSD), or "io1" (provisioned IOPS SSD). The default is "io1" if iops is
specified, "standard" if not. Note that this behaviour is different from the AWS
web console, where the default is "gp2".

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.

args.name: timezone
args.description:
(Optional) Time zone of the DB instance. timezone is currently
only supported by Microsoft SQL Server. The timezone can only be set on
creation. See MSSQL User
Guide
for more information.

args.name: username
args.description:
(Required unless a snapshot_identifier or replicate_source_db
is provided) Username for the master DB user.

args.name: vpc_security_group_ids
args.description:
(Optional) List of VPC security groups to
associate.

args.name: create
args.description:
(Default 40 minutes) Used for Creating Instances, Replicas, and
restoring from Snapshots.

args.name: update
args.description: (Default 80 minutes) Used for Database modifications.

args.name: delete
args.description:
(Default 40 minutes) Used for destroying databases. This includes
the time required to take snapshots.

DB instance.

in a Route 53 Alias record).

args.description: (Optional) Name for an automatically created database on cluster creation. There are different naming restrictions per database engine: RDS Naming Constraints

args.description:
(Optional) The name of your final DB snapshot
  when this DB cluster is deleted. If omitted, no final snapshot will be
  made.

args.name: skip_final_snapshot
args.description: (Optional) Determines whether a final DB snapshot is created before the DB cluster is deleted. If true is specified, no DB snapshot is created. If false is specified, a DB snapshot is created before the DB cluster is deleted, using the value from final_snapshot_identifier. Default is false.

args.name: availability_zones
args.description:

instances in the DB cluster can be created in

args.name: backup_retention_period
args.description:
(Optional) The days to retain backups for. Default
1

args.name: preferred_backup_window
args.description:
(Optional) The daily time range during which automated backups are created if automated backups are enabled using the BackupRetentionPeriod parameter.Time in UTC
Default: A 30-minute window selected at random from an 8-hour block of time per region. e.g. 04:00-09:00

args.name: preferred_maintenance_window
args.description: (Optional) The weekly time range during which system maintenance can occur, in (UTC) e.g. wed:04:00-wed:04:30

args.name: port
args.description: (Optional) The port on which the DB accepts connections

args.name: vpc_security_group_ids
args.description:

with the Cluster

args.description: (Optional) Specifies whether or not to create this cluster from a snapshot. This correlates to the snapshot ID you'd find in the RDS console, e.g: rds:production-2015-06-26-06-05.

args.name: storage_encrypted
args.description: (Optional) Specifies whether the DB cluster is encrypted. The default is false if not specified.

args.name: apply_immediately
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies whether any cluster modifications
   are applied immediately, or during the next maintenance window. Default is
   false. See Amazon RDS Documentation for more information.

args.name: db_subnet_group_name
args.description: (Optional) A DB subnet group to associate with this DB instance. NOTE: This must match the db_subnet_group_name specified on every aws_rds_cluster_instance in the cluster.

args.name: db_cluster_parameter_group_name
args.description: (Optional) A cluster parameter group to associate with the cluster.

args.name: kms_key_id
args.description: (Optional) The ARN for the KMS encryption key. When specifying kms_key_id, storage_encrypted needs to be set to true.

args.name: iam_roles
args.description: (Optional) A List of ARNs for the IAM roles to associate to the RDS Cluster.

args.name: iam_database_authentication_enabled
args.description: (Optional) Specifies whether or mappings of AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) accounts to database accounts is enabled.

args.name: engine
args.description: (Optional) The name of the database engine to be used for this DB cluster. Defaults to aurora.

args.name: engine_version
args.description: (Optional) The database engine version.

args.name: identifier
args.description: (Optional, Forces new resource) The indentifier for the RDS instance, if omitted, Terraform will assign a random, unique identifier.

args.name: identifier_prefix
args.description: (Optional, Forces new resource) Creates a unique identifier beginning with the specified prefix. Conflicts with identifer.

args.name: cluster_identifier
args.description: (Required) The identifier of the aws_rds_cluster in which to launch this instance.

args.name: engine
args.description: (Optional) The name of the database engine to be used for the RDS instance. Defaults to aurora.

args.name: engine_version
args.description: (Optional) The database engine version.

args.name: instance_class
args.description:
(Required) The instance class to use. For details on CPU
and memory, see Scaling Aurora DB Instances. Aurora currently
supports the below instance classes.
db.t2.small
db.t2.medium
db.r3.large
db.r3.xlarge
db.r3.2xlarge
db.r3.4xlarge
db.r3.8xlarge

args.name: publicly_accessible
args.description:
(Optional) Bool to control if instance is publicly accessible.
Default false. See the documentation on Creating DB Instances for more
details on controlling this property.

args.name: db_subnet_group_name
args.description: (Required if publicly_accessible = false, Optional otherwise) A DB subnet group to associate with this DB instance. NOTE: This must match the db_subnet_group_name of the attached aws_rds_cluster.

args.name: db_parameter_group_name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the DB parameter group to associate with this instance.

args.name: apply_immediately
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies whether any database modifications
   are applied immediately, or during the next maintenance window. Default isfalse.

args.name: monitoring_role_arn
args.description:
(Optional) The ARN for the IAM role that permits RDS to send
enhanced monitoring metrics to CloudWatch Logs. You can find more information on the AWS Documentation
what IAM permissions are needed to allow Enhanced Monitoring for RDS Instances.

args.name: monitoring_interval
args.description: (Optional) The interval, in seconds, between points when Enhanced Monitoring metrics are collected for the DB instance. To disable collecting Enhanced Monitoring metrics, specify 0. The default is 0. Valid Values: 0, 1, 5, 10, 15, 30, 60.

args.name: promotion_tier
args.description: (Optional) Default 0. Failover Priority setting on instance level. The reader who has lower tier has higher priority to get promoter to writer.

args.name: availability_zone
args.description: (Optional, Computed) The EC2 Availability Zone that the DB instance is created in. See docs about the details.

args.name: preferred_backup_window
args.description:
(Optional) The daily time range during which automated backups are created if automated backups are enabled.
Eg: "04:00-09:00"

args.name: preferred_maintenance_window
args.description:
(Optional) The window to perform maintenance in.
Syntax: "ddd:hh24:mi-ddd:hh24:mi". Eg: "Mon:00:00-Mon:03:00".

args.name: auto_minor_version_upgrade
args.description: (Optional) Indicates that minor engine upgrades will be applied automatically to the DB instance during the maintenance window. Default true.

args.name: performance_insights_enabled
args.description: (Optional) Specifies whether Performance Insights is enabled or not.

args.name: performance_insights_kms_key_id
args.description: (Optional) The ARN for the KMS key to encrypt Performance Insights data. When specifying performance_insights_kms_key_id, performance_insights_enabled needs to be set to true.

args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the instance.

args.description: (Optional) A list of Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) security groups to be associated with the cluster.

args.name: cluster_subnet_group_name
args.description: (Optional) The name of a cluster subnet group to be associated with this cluster. If this parameter is not provided the resulting cluster will be deployed outside virtual private cloud (VPC).

args.name: availability_zone
args.description: (Optional) The EC2 Availability Zone (AZ) in which you want Amazon Redshift to provision the cluster. For example, if you have several EC2 instances running in a specific Availability Zone, then you might want the cluster to be provisioned in the same zone in order to decrease network latency.

args.name: preferred_maintenance_window
args.description: (Optional) The weekly time range (in UTC) during which automated cluster maintenance can occur.                                        Format: ddd:hh24:mi-ddd:hh24:mi

args.name: cluster_parameter_group_name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the parameter group to be associated with this cluster.

args.name: automated_snapshot_retention_period
args.description: (Optional) The number of days that automated snapshots are retained. If the value is 0, automated snapshots are disabled. Even if automated snapshots are disabled, you can still create manual snapshots when you want with create-cluster-snapshot. Default is 1.

args.name: port
args.description: (Optional) The port number on which the cluster accepts incoming connections.                The cluster is accessible only via the JDBC and ODBC connection strings. Part of the connection string requires the port on which the cluster will listen for incoming connections. Default port is 5439.

args.name: cluster_version
args.description: (Optional) The version of the Amazon Redshift engine software that you want to deploy on the cluster.                           The version selected runs on all the nodes in the cluster.

args.name: allow_version_upgrade
args.description: (Optional) If true , major version upgrades can be applied during the maintenance window to the Amazon Redshift engine that is running on the cluster. Default is true

args.name: number_of_nodes
args.description: (Optional) The number of compute nodes in the cluster. This parameter is required when the ClusterType parameter is specified as multi-node. Default is 1.

args.name: publicly_accessible
args.description: (Optional) If true, the cluster can be accessed from a public network. Default is true.

args.name: encrypted
args.description: (Optional) If true , the data in the cluster is encrypted at rest.

args.name: enhanced_vpc_routing
args.description: (Optional) If true , enhanced VPC routing is enabled.

args.name: kms_key_id
args.description: (Optional) The ARN for the KMS encryption key. When specifying kms_key_id, encrypted needs to be set to true.

args.name: elastic_ip
args.description: (Optional) The Elastic IP (EIP) address for the cluster.

args.name: skip_final_snapshot
args.description: (Optional) Determines whether a final snapshot of the cluster is created before Amazon Redshift deletes the cluster. If true , a final cluster snapshot is not created. If false , a final cluster snapshot is created before the cluster is deleted. Default is false.

args.name: final_snapshot_identifier
args.description: (Optional) The identifier of the final snapshot that is to be created immediately before deleting the cluster. If this parameter is provided, skip_final_snapshot must be false.

args.name: snapshot_identifier
args.description: (Optional) The name of the snapshot from which to create the new cluster.

args.name: snapshot_cluster_identifier
args.description: (Optional) The name of the cluster the source snapshot was created from.

args.name: owner_account
args.description: (Optional) The AWS customer account used to create or copy the snapshot. Required if you are restoring a snapshot you do not own, optional if you own the snapshot.

args.name: iam_roles
args.description: (Optional) A list of IAM Role ARNs to associate with the cluster. A Maximum of 10 can be associated to the cluster at any time.

args.name: logging
args.description: (Optional) Logging, documented below.

args.name: enable
args.description: (Required) Enables logging information such as queries and connection attempts, for the specified Amazon Redshift cluster.

args.name: bucket_name
args.description:
(Optional, required when enable_logging is true) The name of an existing S3 bucket where the log files are to be stored. Must be in the same region as the cluster and the cluster must have read bucket and put object permissions.
For more information on the permissions required for the bucket, please read the AWS documentation

args.name: s3_key_prefix
args.description: (Optional) The prefix applied to the log file names.

args.name: snapshot_copy
args.description: (Optional) Configuration of automatic copy of snapshots from one region to another. Documented below.

args.name: destination_region
args.description: (Required) The destination region that you want to copy snapshots to.

args.name: retention_period
args.description: (Optional) The number of days to retain automated snapshots in the destination region after they are copied from the source region. Defaults to 7.

args.name: grant_name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the snapshot copy grant to use when snapshots of an AWS KMS-encrypted cluster are copied to the destination region.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name or description of the Byte Match Set.

args.name: byte_match_tuples
args.description:
Specifies the bytes (typically a string that corresponds
with ASCII characters) that you want to search for in web requests,
the location in requests that you want to search, and other settings.

args.name: field_to_match
args.description: (Required) The part of a web request that you want to search, such as a specified header or a query string.

args.name: positional_constraint
args.description:
(Required) Within the portion of a web request that you want to search
(for example, in the query string, if any), specify where you want to search.
e.g. CONTAINS, CONTAINS_WORD or EXACTLY.
See docs
for all supported values.

args.name: target_string
args.description:
(Optional) The value that you want to search for. e.g. HEADER, METHOD or BODY.
See docs
for all supported values.

args.name: text_transformation
args.description:
(Required) Text transformations used to eliminate unusual formatting that attackers use in web requests in an effort to bypass AWS WAF.
If you specify a transformation, AWS WAF performs the transformation on target_string before inspecting a request for a match.
e.g. CMD_LINE, HTML_ENTITY_DECODE or NONE.
See docs
for all supported values.

args.name: data
args.description:
(Optional) When type is HEADER, enter the name of the header that you want to search, e.g. User-Agent or Referer.
If type is any other value, omit this field.

args.name: type
args.description:
(Required) The part of the web request that you want AWS WAF to search for a specified string.
e.g. HEADER, METHOD or BODY.
See docs
for all supported values.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ID of the WAF Byte Match Set.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name or description of the IPSet.

args.name: ip_set_descriptors
args.description:
(Optional) Specifies the IP address type (IPV4 or IPV6)
  and the IP address range (in CIDR format) that web requests originate from.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) Type of the IP address - IPV4 or IPV6.

args.name: value
args.description:
(Required) An IPv4 or IPv6 address specified via CIDR notation.
  e.g. 192.0.2.44/32 or 1111:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000/64

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ID of the WAF IPSet.

args.name: metric_name
args.description: (Required) The name or description for the Amazon CloudWatch metric of this rule.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name or description of the rule.

args.name: predicates
args.description: (Optional) One of ByteMatchSet, IPSet, SizeConstraintSet, SqlInjectionMatchSet, or XssMatchSet objects to include in a rule.

args.name: negated
args.description:
(Required) Set this to false if you want to allow, block, or count requests
based on the settings in the specified ByteMatchSet, IPSet, SqlInjectionMatchSet, XssMatchSet, or SizeConstraintSet.
For example, if an IPSet includes the IP address 192.0.2.44, AWS WAF will allow or block requests based on that IP address.
If set to true, AWS WAF will allow, block, or count requests based on all IP addresses except 192.0.2.44.

args.name: data_id
args.description: (Required) A unique identifier for a predicate in the rule, such as Byte Match Set ID or IPSet ID.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The type of predicate in a rule, such as ByteMatchSet or IPSet

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ID of the WAF rule.

args.name: metric_name
args.description: (Required) The name or description for the Amazon CloudWatch metric of this rule.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name or description of the rule.

args.name: rate_key
args.description: (Required) Valid value is IP.

args.name: rate_limit
args.description: (Required) The maximum number of requests, which have an identical value in the field specified by the RateKey, allowed in a five-minute period. Minimum value is 2000.

args.name: predicates
args.description: (Optional) One of ByteMatchSet, IPSet, SizeConstraintSet, SqlInjectionMatchSet, or XssMatchSet objects to include in a rule.

args.name: negated
args.description:
(Required) Set this to false if you want to allow, block, or count requests
based on the settings in the specified ByteMatchSet, IPSet, SqlInjectionMatchSet, XssMatchSet, or SizeConstraintSet.
For example, if an IPSet includes the IP address 192.0.2.44, AWS WAF will allow or block requests based on that IP address.
If set to true, AWS WAF will allow, block, or count requests based on all IP addresses except 192.0.2.44.

args.name: data_id
args.description: (Required) A unique identifier for a predicate in the rule, such as Byte Match Set ID or IPSet ID.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The type of predicate in a rule, such as ByteMatchSet or IPSet

attrs.name: id

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name or description of the Size Constraint Set.

args.name: size_constraints
args.description: (Optional) Specifies the parts of web requests that you want to inspect the size of.

args.name: field_to_match
args.description: (Required) Specifies where in a web request to look for the size constraint.

args.name: comparison_operator
args.description:
(Required) The type of comparison you want to perform.
e.g. EQ, NE, LT, GT.
See docs for all supported values.

args.name: size
args.description:
(Required) The size in bytes that you want to compare against the size of the specified field_to_match.
Valid values are between 0 - 21474836480 bytes (0 - 20 GB).

args.name: text_transformation
args.description:
(Required) Text transformations used to eliminate unusual formatting that attackers use in web requests in an effort to bypass AWS WAF.
If you specify a transformation, AWS WAF performs the transformation on field_to_match before inspecting a request for a match.
e.g. CMD_LINE, HTML_ENTITY_DECODE or NONE.
See docs
for all supported values.
Note: if you choose BODY as type, you must choose NONE because CloudFront forwards only the first 8192 bytes for inspection.

args.name: data
args.description:
(Optional) When type is HEADER, enter the name of the header that you want to search, e.g. User-Agent or Referer.
If type is any other value, omit this field.

args.name: type
args.description:
(Required) The part of the web request that you want AWS WAF to search for a specified string.
e.g. HEADER, METHOD or BODY.
See docs
for all supported values.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ID of the WAF Size Constraint Set.

args.name: field_to_match
args.description: (Required) Specifies where in a web request to look for snippets of malicious SQL code.

(Required) Text transformations used to eliminate unusual formatting that attackers use in web requests in an effort to bypass AWS WAF.
If you specify a transformation, AWS WAF performs the transformation on field_to_match before inspecting a request for a match.
e.g. CMD_LINE, HTML_ENTITY_DECODE or NONE.
See docs
for all supported values.

args.name: data
args.description:
(Optional) When type is HEADER, enter the name of the header that you want to search, e.g. User-Agent or Referer.
If type is any other value, omit this field.

args.description:

e.g. ALLOW, BLOCK or COUNT

args.name: priority

Rules with a lower value are evaluated before rules with a higher value.

args.name: type

attrs.name: id

args.name: reference_name
args.description:
(Optional) This is a reference name used in Caller Reference
  (helpful for identifying single health_check set amongst others)

args.name: fqdn
args.description: (Optional) The fully qualified domain name of the endpoint to be checked.

args.name: ip_address
args.description: (Optional) The IP address of the endpoint to be checked.

args.name: port
args.description: (Optional) The port of the endpoint to be checked.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The protocol to use when performing health checks. Valid values are HTTP, HTTPS, HTTP_STR_MATCH, HTTPS_STR_MATCH, TCP, CALCULATED and CLOUDWATCH_METRIC.

args.name: failure_threshold
args.description: (Required) The number of consecutive health checks that an endpoint must pass or fail.

args.name: request_interval
args.description: (Required) The number of seconds between the time that Amazon Route 53 gets a response from your endpoint and the time that it sends the next health-check request.

args.name: resource_path
args.description: (Optional) The path that you want Amazon Route 53 to request when performing health checks.

args.name: search_string
args.description: (Optional) String searched in the first 5120 bytes of the response body for check to be considered healthy.

args.name: measure_latency
args.description: (Optional) A Boolean value that indicates whether you want Route 53 to measure the latency between health checkers in multiple AWS regions and your endpoint and to display CloudWatch latency graphs in the Route 53 console.

args.name: invert_healthcheck
args.description: (Optional) A boolean value that indicates whether the status of health check should be inverted. For example, if a health check is healthy but Inverted is True , then Route 53 considers the health check to be unhealthy.

args.name: enable_sni
args.description: (Optional) A boolean value that indicates whether Route53 should send the fqdn to the endpoint when performing the health check. This defaults to AWS' defaults: when the type is "HTTPS" enable_sni defaults to true, when type is anything else enable_sni defaults to false.

args.name: child_healthchecks
args.description: (Optional) For a specified parent health check, a list of HealthCheckId values for the associated child health checks.

args.name: child_health_threshold
args.description: (Optional) The minimum number of child health checks that must be healthy for Route 53 to consider the parent health check to be healthy. Valid values are integers between 0 and 256, inclusive

args.name: cloudwatch_alarm_name
args.description: (Optional) The name of the CloudWatch alarm.

args.name: cloudwatch_alarm_region
args.description: (Optional) The CloudWatchRegion that the CloudWatch alarm was created in.

args.name: insufficient_data_health_status
args.description: (Optional) The status of the health check when CloudWatch has insufficient data about the state of associated alarm. Valid values are Healthy , Unhealthy and LastKnownStatus.

args.name: regions
args.description: (Optional) A list of AWS regions that you want Amazon Route 53 health checkers to check the specified endpoint from.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the health check.

args.name: cloudwatch_log_group_arn
args.description: (Required) CloudWatch log group ARN to send query logs.

args.name: zone_id
args.description: (Required) Route53 hosted zone ID to enable query logs.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The query logging configuration ID

args.name: zone_id
args.description: (Required) The ID of the hosted zone to contain this record.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the record.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The record type. Valid values are A, AAAA, CAA, CNAME, MX, NAPTR, NS, PTR, SOA, SPF, SRV and TXT.

args.name: ttl
args.description: (Required for non-alias records) The TTL of the record.

args.name: records
args.description: (Required for non-alias records) A string list of records. To specify a single record value longer than 255 characters such as a TXT record for DKIM, add \"\" inside the Terraform configuration string (e.g. "first255characters\"\"morecharacters").

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) DNS domain name for a CloudFront distribution, S3 bucket, ELB, or another resource record set in this hosted zone.

args.name: zone_id
args.description: (Required) Hosted zone ID for a CloudFront distribution, S3 bucket, ELB, or Route 53 hosted zone. See resource_elb.zone_id for example.

args.name: evaluate_target_health
args.description: (Required) Set to true if you want Route 53 to determine whether to respond to DNS queries using this resource record set by checking the health of the resource record set. Some resources have special requirements, see related part of documentation.

args.name: set_identifier
args.description: (Optional) Unique identifier to differentiate records with routing policies from one another. Required if using failover, geolocation, latency, or weighted routing policies documented below.

args.name: health_check_id
args.description: (Optional) The health check the record should be associated with.

args.name: alias
args.description:
(Optional) An alias block. Conflicts with ttl & records.
Alias record documented below.

args.name: failover_routing_policy
args.description: (Optional) A block indicating the routing behavior when associated health check fails. Conflicts with any other routing policy. Documented below.

args.name: geolocation_routing_policy
args.description: (Optional) A block indicating a routing policy based on the geolocation of the requestor. Conflicts with any other routing policy. Documented below.

args.name: latency_routing_policy
args.description: (Optional) A block indicating a routing policy based on the latency between the requestor and an AWS region. Conflicts with any other routing policy. Documented below.

args.name: weighted_routing_policy
args.description: (Optional) A block indicating a weighted routing policy. Conflicts with any other routing policy. Documented below.

args.name: multivalue_answer_routing_policy
args.description: (Optional) A block indicating a multivalue answer routing policy. Conflicts with any other routing policy.

args.name: allow_overwrite
args.description: (Optional) Allow creation of this record in Terraform to overwrite an existing record, if any. This does not prevent other resources within Terraform or manual Route53 changes from overwriting this record. true by default.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) PRIMARY or SECONDARY. A PRIMARY record will be served if its healthcheck is passing, otherwise the SECONDARY will be served. See http://docs.aws.amazon.com/Route53/latest/DeveloperGuide/dns-failover-configuring-options.html#dns-failover-failover-rrsets

args.name: continent
args.description: A two-letter continent code. See http://docs.aws.amazon.com/Route53/latest/APIReference/API_GetGeoLocation.html for code details. Either continent or country must be specified.

args.name: country
args.description: A two-character country code or * to indicate a default resource record set.

args.name: subdivision
args.description: (Optional) A subdivision code for a country.

args.name: region
args.description: (Required) An AWS region from which to measure latency. See http://docs.aws.amazon.com/Route53/latest/DeveloperGuide/routing-policy.html#routing-policy-latency

args.name: weight
args.description: (Required) A numeric value indicating the relative weight of the record. See http://docs.aws.amazon.com/Route53/latest/DeveloperGuide/routing-policy.html#routing-policy-weighted.

attrs.name: fqdn
attrs.description: FQDN built using the zone domain and name

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) This is the name of the hosted zone.

args.name: comment
args.description: (Optional) A comment for the hosted zone. Defaults to 'Managed by Terraform'.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the zone.

args.name: vpc_id
args.description:
(Optional) The VPC to associate with a private hosted zone. Specifying vpc_id will create a private hosted zone.
Conflicts w/ delegation_set_id as delegation sets can only be used for public zones.

args.name: vpc_region
args.description: (Optional) The VPC's region. Defaults to the region of the AWS provider.

args.name: delegation_set_id
args.description:
(Optional) The ID of the reusable delegation set whose NS records you want to assign to the hosted zone.

args.name: bucket

args.description: (Optional, Forces new resource) Creates a unique bucket name beginning with the specified prefix. Conflicts with bucket.

args.name: acl
args.description: (Optional) The canned ACL to apply. Defaults to "private".

args.name: policy
args.description: (Optional) A valid bucket policy JSON document. Note that if the policy document is not specific enough (but still valid), Terraform may view the policy as constantly changing in a terraform plan. In this case, please make sure you use the verbose/specific version of the policy.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the bucket.

args.description: (Optional, Default:false ) A boolean that indicates all objects should be deleted from the bucket so that the bucket can be destroyed without error. These objects are not recoverable.

args.description: (Optional) A website object (documented below).

args.description: (Required, unless using redirect_all_requests_to) Amazon S3 returns this index document when requests are made to the root domain or any of the subfolders.

args.description: (Optional) An absolute path to the document to return in case of a 4XX error.

args.name: redirect_all_requests_to
args.description: (Optional) A hostname to redirect all website requests for this bucket to. Hostname can optionally be prefixed with a protocol (http:// or https://) to use when redirecting requests. The default is the protocol that is used in the original request.

args.description:

args.name: mfa_delete
args.description: (Optional) Enable MFA delete for either Change the versioning state of your bucket or Permanently delete an object version. Default is false.

developer guide for more information.

attrs.name: verification_token
attrs.description:
A code which when added to the domain as a TXT record
will signal to SES that the owner of the domain has authorised SES to act on
their behalf. The domain identity will be in state "verification pending"
until this is done. See below for an example of how this might be achieved
when the domain is hosted in Route 53 and managed by Terraform.  Find out
more about verifying domains in Amazon SES in the AWS SES
docs.

args.name: domain

attrs.name: dkim_tokens
attrs.description:
DKIM tokens generated by SES.
These tokens should be used to create CNAME records used to verify SES Easy DKIM.
See below for an example of how this might be achieved
when the domain is hosted in Route 53 and managed by Terraform. 
Find out more about verifying domains in Amazon SES 
in the AWS SES docs.

args.description: (Required) The ARN of the SNS topic

args.name: policy
args.description: (Required) The fully-formed AWS policy as JSON

args.name: topic_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the SNS topic to subscribe to

args.name: protocol
args.description: (Required) The protocol to use. The possible values for this are: sqs, sms, lambda, application. (http or https are partially supported, see below) (email is option but unsupported, see below).

args.name: lambda
args.description: - delivery of JSON-encoded message to a lambda function

args.name: sqs
args.description: - delivery of JSON-encoded message to an Amazon SQS queue

args.name: application
args.description: - delivery of JSON-encoded message to an EndpointArn for a mobile app and device

args.name: sms
args.description: - delivery text message

args.name: http
args.description: - delivery of JSON-encoded messages via HTTP. Supported only for the end points that auto confirms the subscription.

args.name: https
args.description: - delivery of JSON-encoded messages via HTTPS. Supported only for the end points that auto confirms the subscription.

args.name: email
args.description: - delivery of message via SMTP

args.name: endpoint
args.description: (Required) The endpoint to send data to, the contents will vary with the protocol. (see below for more information)

args.name: endpoint_auto_confirms
args.description: (Optional) Boolean indicating whether the end point is capable of auto confirming subscription e.g., PagerDuty (default is false)

args.name: confirmation_timeout_in_minutes
args.description: (Optional) Integer indicating number of minutes to wait in retying mode for fetching subscription arn before marking it as failure. Only applicable for http and https protocols (default is 1 minute).

args.name: raw_message_delivery
args.description: (Optional) Boolean indicating whether or not to enable raw message delivery (the original message is directly passed, not wrapped in JSON with the original message in the message property) (default is false).

args.name: filter_policy
args.description: (Optional) The text of a filter policy to the topic subscription.

args.name: name

args.name: schedule
args.description: (Required) The schedule of the Maintenance Window in the form of a cron or rate expression.

args.name: cutoff
args.description: (Required) The number of hours before the end of the Maintenance Window that Systems Manager stops scheduling new tasks for execution.

args.name: duration
args.description: (Required) The duration of the Maintenance Window in hours.

args.name: allow_unassociated_targets
args.description: (Optional) Whether targets must be registered with the Maintenance Window before tasks can be defined for those targets.

args.description: (Required) The Id of the maintenance window to register the target with.

args.name: resource_type
args.description: (Required) The type of target being registered with the Maintenance Window. Possible values INSTANCE.

args.name: targets
args.description: (Required) The targets (either instances or tags). Instances are specified using Key=instanceids,Values=instanceid1,instanceid2. Tags are specified using Key=tag name,Values=tag value.

args.name: owner_information
args.description: (Optional) User-provided value that will be included in any CloudWatch events raised while running tasks for these targets in this Maintenance Window.

attrs.name: id

args.description: (Required) The Id of the maintenance window to register the task with.

args.name: max_concurrency
args.description: (Required) The maximum number of targets this task can be run for in parallel.

args.name: max_errors
args.description: (Required) The maximum number of errors allowed before this task stops being scheduled.

args.name: task_type
args.description: (Required) The type of task being registered. The only allowed value is RUN_COMMAND.

args.name: task_arn
args.description: (Required) The ARN of the task to execute.

args.name: service_role_arn
args.description: (Required) The role that should be assumed when executing the task.

args.name: targets
args.description: (Required) The targets (either instances or window target ids). Instances are specified using Key=InstanceIds,Values=instanceid1,instanceid2. Window target ids are specified using Key=WindowTargetIds,Values=window target id1, window target id2.

args.name: priority
args.description: (Optional) The priority of the task in the Maintenance Window, the lower the number the higher the priority. Tasks in a Maintenance Window are scheduled in priority order with tasks that have the same priority scheduled in parallel.

args.name: name
args.description: (Required) The name of the patch baseline.

args.name: description
args.description: (Optional) The description of the patch baseline.

args.name: operating_system
args.description: (Optional) Defines the operating system the patch baseline applies to. Supported operating systems include WINDOWS, AMAZON_LINUX, UBUNTU and REDHAT_ENTERPRISE_LINUX. The Default value is WINDOWS.

args.name: approved_patches_compliance_level
args.description: (Optional) Defines the compliance level for approved patches. This means that if an approved patch is reported as missing, this is the severity of the compliance violation. Valid compliance levels include the following: CRITICAL, HIGH, MEDIUM, LOW, INFORMATIONAL, UNSPECIFIED. The default value is UNSPECIFIED.

args.name: approved_patches
args.description: (Optional) A list of explicitly approved patches for the baseline.

args.name: rejected_patches
args.description: (Optional) A list of rejected patches.

args.name: global_filter
args.description: (Optional) A set of global filters used to exclude patches from the baseline. Up to 4 global filters can be specified using Key/Value pairs. Valid Keys are PRODUCT | CLASSIFICATION | MSRC_SEVERITY | PATCH_ID.

args.name: approval_rule
args.description: (Optional) A set of rules used to include patches in the baseline. up to 10 approval rules can be specified. Each approval_rule block requires the fields documented below.

args.name: approve_after_days
args.description: (Required) The number of days after the release date of each patch matched by the rule the patch is marked as approved in the patch baseline. Valid Range: 0 to 100.

args.name: patch_filter
args.description: (Required) The patch filter group that defines the criteria for the rule. Up to 4 patch filters can be specified per approval rule using Key/Value pairs. Valid Keys are PRODUCT | CLASSIFICATION | MSRC_SEVERITY | PATCH_ID.

args.name: compliance_level
args.description: (Optional) Defines the compliance level for patches approved by this rule. Valid compliance levels include the following: CRITICAL, HIGH, MEDIUM, LOW, INFORMATIONAL, UNSPECIFIED. The default value is UNSPECIFIED.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ID of the patch baseline.

args.name: baseline_id
args.description: (Required) The ID of the patch baseline to register the patch group with.

args.name: patch_group
args.description: (Required) The name of the patch group that should be registered with the patch baseline.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ID of the patch baseline.

args.description: (Required) Name of S3 bucket where the aggregated data is stored.

args.description: (Required) Region with the bucket targeted by the Resource Data Sync.

args.description: (Optional) ARN of an encryption key for a destination in Amazon S3.

args.description: (Optional) Prefix for the bucket.

args.description: (Optional) A supported sync format. Only JsonSerDe is currently supported. Defaults to JsonSerDe.

args.name: name
args.description: (Optional) This is the human-readable name of the queue. If omitted, Terraform will assign a random name.

args.name: name_prefix
args.description: (Optional) Creates a unique name beginning with the specified prefix. Conflicts with name.

args.name: visibility_timeout_seconds
args.description: (Optional) The visibility timeout for the queue. An integer from 0 to 43200 (12 hours). The default for this attribute is 30. For more information about visibility timeout, see AWS docs.

args.name: message_retention_seconds
args.description: (Optional) The number of seconds Amazon SQS retains a message. Integer representing seconds, from 60 (1 minute) to 1209600 (14 days). The default for this attribute is 345600 (4 days).

args.name: max_message_size
args.description: (Optional) The limit of how many bytes a message can contain before Amazon SQS rejects it. An integer from 1024 bytes (1 KiB) up to 262144 bytes (256 KiB). The default for this attribute is 262144 (256 KiB).

args.name: delay_seconds
args.description: (Optional) The time in seconds that the delivery of all messages in the queue will be delayed. An integer from 0 to 900 (15 minutes). The default for this attribute is 0 seconds.

args.name: receive_wait_time_seconds
args.description: (Optional) The time for which a ReceiveMessage call will wait for a message to arrive (long polling) before returning. An integer from 0 to 20 (seconds). The default for this attribute is 0, meaning that the call will return immediately.

args.name: policy
args.description: (Optional) The JSON policy for the SQS queue

args.name: redrive_policy
args.description: (Optional) The JSON policy to set up the Dead Letter Queue, see AWS docs. Note: when specifying maxReceiveCount, you must specify it as an integer (5), and not a string ("5").

args.name: fifo_queue
args.description: (Optional) Boolean designating a FIFO queue. If not set, it defaults to false making it standard.

args.name: content_based_deduplication
args.description: (Optional) Enables content-based deduplication for FIFO queues. For more information, see the related documentation

args.name: kms_master_key_id
args.description: (Optional) The ID of an AWS-managed customer master key (CMK) for Amazon SQS or a custom CMK. For more information, see Key Terms.

args.name: kms_data_key_reuse_period_seconds
args.description: (Optional) The length of time, in seconds, for which Amazon SQS can reuse a data key to encrypt or decrypt messages before calling AWS KMS again. An integer representing seconds, between 60 seconds (1 minute) and 86,400 seconds (24 hours). The default is 300 (5 minutes).

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the queue.

args.name: revoke_rules_on_delete
args.description:
(Optional) Instruct Terraform to revoke all of the
Security Groups attached ingress and egress rules before deleting the rule
itself. This is normally not needed, however certain AWS services such as
Elastic Map Reduce may automatically add required rules to security groups used
with the service, and those rules may contain a cyclic dependency that prevent
the security groups from being destroyed without removing the dependency first.
Default false

args.name: accepter
args.description:
(Optional)  An optional configuration block that allows for [VPC Peering Connection]
(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonVPC/latest/PeeringGuide) options to be set for the VPC that accepts
the peering connection (a maximum of one).

args.name: requester
args.description:
(Optional)  A optional configuration block that allows for [VPC Peering Connection]
(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonVPC/latest/PeeringGuide) options to be set for the VPC that requests
the peering connection (a maximum of one).

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.

args.name: allow_remote_vpc_dns_resolution
args.description:
(Optional) Allow a local VPC to resolve public DNS hostnames to private
IP addresses when queried from instances in the peer VPC.

args.name: allow_classic_link_to_remote_vpc
args.description:
(Optional) Allow a local linked EC2-Classic instance to communicate
with instances in a peer VPC. This enables an outbound communication from the local ClassicLink connection
to the remote VPC.

args.name: allow_vpc_to_remote_classic_link
args.description:
(Optional) Allow a local VPC to communicate with a linked EC2-Classic
instance in a peer VPC. This enables an outbound communication from the local VPC to the remote ClassicLink
connection.

attrs.name: id
attrs.description: The ID of the VPC Peering Connection.

attrs.name: accept_status
attrs.description: The status of the VPC Peering Connection request.

args.name: vpc_peering_connection_id
args.description: (Required) The VPC Peering Connection ID to manage.

args.name: auto_accept
args.description: (Optional) Whether or not to accept the peering request. Defaults to false.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.

args.name: customer_gateway_id
args.description: (Required) The ID of the customer gateway.

args.name: static_routes_only
args.description: (Optional, Default false) Whether the VPN connection uses static routes exclusively. Static routes must be used for devices that don't support BGP.

args.name: tags
args.description: (Optional) Tags to apply to the connection.

args.name: type
args.description: (Required) The type of VPN connection. The only type AWS supports at this time is "ipsec.1".

args.name: vpn_gateway_id
args.description: (Required) The ID of the virtual private gateway.

args.name: tunnel1_inside_cidr
args.description: (Optional) The CIDR block of the inside IP addresses for the first VPN tunnel.

args.name: tunnel2_inside_cidr
args.description: (Optional) The CIDR block of the second IP addresses for the first VPN tunnel.

args.name: tunnel1_preshared_key
args.description: (Optional) The preshared key of the first VPN tunnel.

args.name: tunnel2_preshared_key
args.description: (Optional) The preshared key of the second VPN tunnel.
